Dear Sir,

There has been adopted by the Department to submit cost of desks & slates with a new & setting some locally for this school. Regular mail service prevented me from communicating with you before writing, act in consequence I had to get slates & slate pipe.

I have turned over to the Department one slate costing $10.00 & 12 legs of slate pipe at 20 cents each. I had one desk bench made which cost $4.00.

Hope your Department will see that I could not wait long enough to communicate with you but had to get these things & now submit same for your consideration amounting to $16.00.

Enclosed also please find school report for quarter ending 20th.

Yours sincerely,

C.F.

THE SECRETARY

DEPT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

OTTAWA
Sir:

Re detachment building at Split Lake
(Your File 143/1917)

In answer to your memo. of the last instant, would beg
to advise you that the quarters formerly used by our detachment
stationed at Split Lake, consist of a log building, the in-
side dimensions of which are 24' X 24', with rubberoid roof,
and was erected during the Summer and Fall of 1907, at an
approximate cost of $1,250.00, including improvements and
alterations which have been made from time to time. When
I last saw this building some two years ago, it impressed
me as being rather a comfortable one for that outlying
section of the country.

It could be readily converted at little expense into a
quite suitable house for school purposes.

It is not likely that we shall ever require the
building again, and I am of the opinion that $1,000.00 would
be a fair valuation to place upon it at the present time.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Commissioner.

The Comptroller,
R. N. W. M. Police,
Ottawa.
Referring to your letter of the 23rd ultimo,
No.306640/1 re building at Split Lake formerly occupied
by the R.N.W.M.Police and which your Department would
like to acquire for school purposes.

In reply I beg to enclose herewith a communication
received from Commissioner A. B. Perry which I think will
give you all the particulars you require.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

for Comptroller.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
Ottawa, March 29, 1917.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant enclosing a communication which you received from Commissioner A. B. Perry in regard to the building at Split Lake formerly occupied by the R.N.W.M. Police.

In reply I have to ask you to be good enough to state whether your Department would allow the use of this building for school purposes and, if so, on what terms.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The Comptroller,
Royal Northwest Mounted Police,
Ottawa.
Sir,

Referring to previous correspondence on the subject of the R.N.W.M. Police detachment building at Split Lake, Man., and particularly to your letter of the 29th March last, file No. 306640/1.

I have now the honour to inform you that the Hon. the Minister has authorized the use of the building above mentioned for school purposes by your Department, rent free, under the conditions set forth in the Order in Council of the 4th May, 1917, copy annexed hereto.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

for Comptroller.

The Asst. Deputy Minister & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, Ont.,
The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a Report, dated 28th April, 1917, from the Acting President of the Privy Council, submitting the following memorandum from the Comptroller of the Royal North West Mounted Police:

"On account of the re-distribution of the Force, the Mounted Police detachment building at Split Lake has been vacated and the Department of Indian Affairs has written this Office requesting to be informed whether the building in question could be obtained by them for school purposes, with the view of establishing a joint school for Indians and Whites at Split Lake in conjunction with the Provincial Government of Manitoba.

The quarters formerly used by our detachment at Split Lake consist of a log building 24' X 24', with rubberoid roof, and was erected during the Summer and Fall of 1907 at an approximate cost of $1,250 including improvements and alterations which have been made from time to time.

The Commissioner reports that it is not likely that the police will ever require the building again and that it could be readily converted at little expense into quite a suitable school house."

The Minister recommends, under the circumstances, that the Department of Indian Affairs be allowed to use the building, rent free, for the above mentioned purpose, provided they keep it in good repair—the necessary alterations to be made at the expense of the Department of Indian Affairs—to which course the Commissioner sees no objection.

The Committee concur in the foregoing and submit the same for approval.

[Signature]

Clerk of the Privy Council.

The Honourable
The Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, May 10, 1917.

Sir,

In connection with previous correspondence relative to the establishment of a joint school for Indians and whites at Split Lake I beg to enclose herewith a copy of an Order in Council allowing the use of the building there formerly occupied by the Royal North West Mounted Police for school purposes.

I should be glad to know what repairs, if any, are necessary to make this building ready for occupation and the probable cost. The Department would be glad if you would undertake to make the necessary arrangements for securing a suitable teacher and opening the school and it will pay two-thirds of the expenses of operation. Kindly furnish the Department with full information as to the name, age, religion, qualifications and experience of the teacher you select.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. Fletcher, Esq.,
Deputy Minister of Education,
Winnipeg, Man.

The Pas, Manitoba,
November 9, 1945.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

I received a communication from Inspector Hamilton, regarding painting the school at Split Lake, in which he refers to your letter of July 26th, File 128-12-1. I have to advise that it was impossible to have this matter attended to last fall, owing to the distance, and the amount of extra work in the office that had to be attended to, but I would appreciate it if I could get the authority to buy the material and have it shipped in this winter, when I could have the work attended to first thing in the spring.

The cost of the material would be as follows:

Outside White (15 gals.) $72.00
Inside White 48.00
Indian labor 125.00

This school really needs decorating, and I would appreciate the authority to go ahead as suggested.

Your obedient servant,

S. Lovell,
Indian Agent.

MEMORANDUM:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Split Lake Indian Day School Teacherage

Included in our 1949-50 Main Estimates is the sum of $5,000.00 for the erection of a teacher's residence at the above Indian Day School situated in the Nelson River Indian Agency, Ilford, Manitoba.

The teacher at this school at the present time is the local Missionary, and his work has proven quite unsatisfactory. Both the Provincial School Inspector and Mr. Clark, our Educational Survey Officer, have reported unfavourably on his work. He is prepared to resign at the end of June, but unfortunately, we have no teacherage available when a new teacher is appointed for next September. The present teacher lives in a Mission residence.

At first, it was understood that we could ship in a small prefabricated house by barge down the river this Spring. However, we have now been advised that this will be impossible. Mr. Indian Superintendent Staunton has fully investigated the possibility of having a prefabricated residence shipped in by tractor train, and we have just received a wire from him reading in part as follows:

"RE SPLIT LAKE TEACHERAGE HAVE LOCATED TRACTOR OPERATOR WHO GUARANTEES DELIVERY AT BUILDING SITE SPLIT LAKE IF MATERIAL DELIVERED BY MARCH ELEVENTH TO ILFORD."
Please find attached a requisition for a small prefabricated house which we have had erected previously and found to be satisfactory for use as a teacher's residence. I would recommend that you approve the purchase of this house so that we can advertise for the services of a qualified teacher at this school for next September. We are arranging a transfer of funds to cover the purchase of the house and will have sufficient funds in our next year's vote to handle the erector's fare and expenses, etc.

Reference your letter of Feb. 10th. on the above, File 543-5 and further to my telegram of even date, please be advised as follows.

Landing River, as mentioned in my previous telegram, is the local name for Mile 279, Hudson Bay Railway, which is approximately Thirty miles from Split Lake Reserve.

Dear Mr. Staunton:

Today is the deadline for the arrival at Ilford of the prefabricated teacherage for Split Lake.

Some weeks later the question of how to furnish it will arise. For your guidance, I enclose two copies of the mimeographed scale of issue of furniture, etc., as supplied to the teacherage of our standard one room school. This house, however, will differ considerable in plan from our teacherage and the problem of furnishing it will be best solved after it has been erected. When that time comes, perhaps you and your wife (to whom please convey my regards) will give this matter your attention and you can then send along a requisition for furniture, etc., drawn up in accordance with this scale to suffice for a man and his wife and a few extras necessary to entertain a couple of people at meals or in the evening. Furnishings for children are not to be anticipated, but if there is an extra bedroom it should be furnished so as to provide stand-by accommodation for official visitors who would otherwise have to stay at the mission or the Hudson's Bay House.

By way of clarifying the picture of school accommodation that may hereafter be stated to be necessary at Split Lake and other points in your superintendency, I enclose a number of blanks of a pro forma which we find useful in surveying prospective needs. It would be helpful to have an exact accounting for the whereabouts of, for instance, 114 children whose names appeared on the Split Lake register in December.
Concerning other concentrations of Indians in your Superintendency, we get letters from time to time from well-meaning people who think we are overlooking something. I had a letter recently from the Churchill Chamber of Commerce which suggested that there are now Indian children there who ought to be in a day school. That reminds me that we have had almost no news at all about the attendance of Indian children at the recently established Provincial Schools at Ilford and York Factory. Perhaps, you have not gone so far afield yet in your snowmobile, but I understand that Corporal McCardle was to go by dog-team to York Factory in February.

I hope that you folks are now comfortably installed in your own home with the furnace functioning.

Yours sincerely,

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Extract from Regional Supervisor Davis' report dated January 4th on the Split Lake Indian Day School.

I only visited the school for a short time, as I was busy visiting the Indians, finding out how many hours a day the school was in operation, and receiving complaints which were numerous. Most of the Indians said it was useless to send their children to school as it only started in the morning around eleven o'clock and closed at twelve; opening again around two or half-past and closing at three o'clock. No effort was made by the Rev. Cowley to teach the children.

When I visited the school there were 12 children in the classroom and an additional 40 were around the homes, who were not attending school. Mr. Grafton advised me that Rev. Cowley claimed that he taught the children in Cree; however, as Mr. Grafton can speak the language and has taught Indian children, it was quite evident that the children were not taught Cree, English or anything else. I would recommend that this man's services be dispensed with and a first class teacher engaged.

As we have not a residence at this point, arrangements should be made to have material sent in before Spring, so we can erect a residence next summer. In the meantime, a teacher could board with the Hudson's Bay Company Post Manager. There is no doubt, that Rev. Cowley has done good Missionary work but the only interest he has had in the school is the salary attached to it.

I beg to acknowledge your letter of above date and number, in reference to supplying a mid-day meal for the children of Swan Lake Day School.

In reply would state, so far as a mid-day meal goes, it would be very nice for the children, but the Indians are of such a roving disposition, that when they go hunting, fishing, visiting, etc., they invariably take the whole family old and young, and the children only getting one meal, in my opinion it would not increase the daily attendance but for a few days at a time, and I think it would be a bad precedent, as there are other nine day schools in my two Agencies and news of this kind travel very fast among the Indians.

Sir—

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th inst. with reference to supplying a mid-day meal at the Swan Lake school, and in reply I beg to say that, in view of the contemplated change of teacher, no action need be taken for a time.

The Department is at present devoting its efforts to the improvement of the day schools in the West, and during the past few months has met with much success at several points. Your opinion that regular attendance can only be secured at boarding or industrial schools is not borne out by the experience of the Department. On several reserves in Saskatchewan there are excellent day schools with good attendance. The primary influence is that of the teacher, who must be devoted to the work, but it has been found that the supplying of a simple mid-day meal is an inducement to regular attendance. On one reserve particularly every available child is registered and all who are well are in attendance.

This matter will be taken up with you again, if you will advise the Department when a new teacher takes charge.

Your obedient Servant,

I beg to report on the Swan Lake Indian Day School which was visited on December the 7th when we were paying Surrendered Land money to this Band.

There were present 10 pupils, 6 boys and 4 girls. The children were not in advanced standards but had a good grasp of the work gone over. They spoke out distinctly and were always ready to take part in any work assigned to them. They were neatly dressed and both pupils and teacher seemed happy in their school surroundings.

The teacher, Miss Bruce, will most likely do very good work. She is a certified teacher of many years experience, being between fifty and sixty years old. Her sister, who is somewhat younger, is engaged by the Presbyterian Church to co-operate with her in this work and so acts as housekeeper, looking after the mid-day meal for the school children. They are cultured ladies and have a good sense of what is wise, so will work harmoniously with any one with whom they shall be required to co-operate, for the advancement of the work on the Reserve.

They were brought up in the city and know very little about country life, and being up in years will not be able to adapt themselves to their surroundings very readily. They seem to be afraid to handle a horse, but they are six miles from Swan Lake and the Indian homes are so far apart that it will be impossible to do much visiting if they have to walk and a horse is almost a necessity.

Dear Sir,

I write to announce to you that I have compelled to close my school last night on account of a severe scourge of wood ticks; a pest I believe peculiar to Manitoba.

The pupils come into school loaded with these and in a few minutes I have them streaming on me, sticking into the floor so incessantly that the blood flows from their heads pulled out. My dear...
Shoulders, neck and ears are a mass of poisoned sores. I have fought this plague during two weeks and have taken every means I could devise for my protection and the extermination of the vermin lurking around in insect poison. Sent the children to pick them off each other (whom these creatures don't appear to trouble) has moved the school out doors, all their precautions and more without any relief; I was getting ill and besides doing no efficient attacking. If you agree, I shall open school in August in order to make up the 11 days still due this term. No one can regret the closing of the school before legitimate time as much as do. Don't you may not think that I have done so lightly.

Sincerely yours,

(Miss) Jessie G. Bruce

Dear Sir,

In answer to your letter of the 5th December asking why the Indian children are not attending school, we would ask you to consider that out of the 25 children mentioned as census return for this Reserve, there are 12 of the pupils now at the Portage Boarding School, leaving 13 very young children, and as some of them have to go 2 & 3 miles they cannot attend the school in very cold or stormy weather. The Indians of this Band want to have all their children sent to school so that they will be able to read and write and understand how to do their own business later on. Also we are having very hard times and sometimes we have to go away to hunt or to work, and as there is no place to leave them, we have to take them with us, but at other times we send them to school as much as we can. It happens some days that the children are not all at school and that was the case the 11th date mentioned in your letter as far as we know the children are attending the school better this fall than they have ever done, and we intend to see that they attend at all times when the weather is good and the people are at home.

If the Dept. would arrange to have the children kept & boarded at the school, during cold weather, and at times when the parents have to go to hunt or work for a living there would not be any trouble about them attending all the time, we would also supply all the wood and vegetables for the School and the Mission.

Dear Mr. McLean,

On April 1st last I wrote you re securing a teacher for Swan Lake Indian Boarding School. At that time I suggested the name of Rev. J.W Fulton. I asked that you give $900 because of his work as teacher and we would make up the balance of his salary and have him do a little missionary work.

I have a letter to-day from Rev. J. A. Cormie, our new District Superintendent for Manitoba, in which he intimates that Rev. J. A. Donaghy would be willing to accept the position. We have written Mr. Donaghy for his qualifications and he writes as follows:

"I am a graduate of Manitoba College in the Minister Evangelist course. I spent a winter on Matriculation work, then entered the M.E. course taking University literature, ethics and Philosophy along with the corresponding M.E. year, that is first year Arts literature etc. with M.E. Theology. I have substituted in local schools at times when the teacher was ill or away for a day or two. Third class teacher's work was being studied in every case by some of the schools. All through the College course I studied the Indians of Canada as a hobby and have considerable knowledge of their origin, customs and languages as well as the psychology of the Indian mind which I studied at first hand for I spent seven years as missionary on the Okanase Mission".

Mr. Donaghy has visited the field and he seems quite willing to accept provided the Indian Department is not planning to sell the Reserve in this vicinity. Apparently there has been some mention made of this.

Kindly let me know if you would approve of the appointment of Mr. Donaghy and at the salary you agreed for Mr. Fulton. He does not seem to have had a Normal training but it is quite impossible to get fully qualified teachers to take up work in these Indian schools at isolated points.

Yours sincerely,

I served the Indians of Swan Lake Reservation nine years as teacher.

Rev. J. H. Edmison, B. A.,

Dear Sir,

I have just received my quarterly cheque representing the Indian Department's share of my salary. I notice it is for $187.50, as was also the last one. I did not write about it as I wished to see how it would go with the June quarter. As my salary from that source is $900.00 per year, and is thus $225.00 per quarter, I cannot understand why these cheques were both $37.50 short. During the first quarter the school lost 7 days through an epidemic among the children and I thought they had charged me up with the lost time. In the June quarter, I taught 61 days, that is, 2 days over what the regulations really demanded. I was trying to make up some of the lost 7 days. But again the cheque is $37.50 behind the amount due. No explanation has accompanied either cheque so would you kindly look into it for me?

If I put in the school year of at least 200 days I will expect to be paid the year's salary by then, namely, $900.00. The regulations state that the September quarter will be paid for as a "broken quarter" that is, they will only pay for actual days taught. If this is so, it looks as though at the end of the year, when I will have completed the school year, that they will be far short of the school year's salary.

Yours truly, (sgd.) Jas. A. Doughy.

P.S. These cheques come to me through the W. M. S. J.A.D.

Extract from Report of Inspector Wood's on the Swan Lake School

School Inspected Dec. 9th, 1922. Original on 20580-5.

Mr. Donaghy is quite interested in his work. I consider him a very suitable teacher for this type of school. If he had some special training in primary work it would help very much. We have a special course for this department in our Teacher's Summer School held in the Agricultural College, Winnipeg, during the month of July. The only expense in connection with this is travel fare and $1.00 per day for board and lodgings. I did not suggest this course to Mr. Donaghy but feel that it is all he requires to make him efficient.
OTTAWA, Dec. 21st, 1922.

Reverend Sir,

In his recent report on the Swan Lake School, Inspector Wood suggests that you take a special course in the Teacher's Summer School, which is conducted in the Agricultural College, Winnipeg, during the month of July. He states that the special training in primary work which is given in this School, would be a considerable help to you.

If you are prepared to take this course the Department would give you an advance next June of $50.00, which amount would no doubt cover your expenses. The Advance would be deducted from your salary in four quarterly instalments, during the School year 1923-24.

If you take the course the Department will increase your salary to $950.00 from September 1st, 1923.

Kindly give this matter your careful consideration and advise me if you will adopt this suggestion. If you decide to do so, it might be advisable to communicate with Inspector Wood, and request him to make the necessary arrangements for you to attend this course.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. J. A. Donaghy,
Teacher,
Swan Lake School,
Indian Springs,
Man.
Dear Sir,

I have just received your letter referring to Inspector Wood's report on this school. He recommends that I take a special course given at the Agricultural College, Winnipeg, which deals with primary teaching.

I do not know his reason for the suggestion, but I drew his attention to the fact that the Indian Department does not supply things essential to the training of very young Indian minds. A white child, you know, comes to school age with its mind loaded with dormant ideas awaiting development. Whereas an Indian child comes to school age with its mind entirely devoid of ideas. These have to be "planted" & then developed. To aid this we acquire special equipment, something to keep them occupied between lessons, otherwise they become restless.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6248, file 544-1, part 1)
I am quite willing to take a copy that will assist me in my work here, as we have a large number of children just about to become of school age, at the same time I have certain doubts as to the special course having much in it that takes into account the psychology of the Indian mind, for this is something in a class by itself.

However, I accept your offer & will write Inspector Wood & that offer.

Yours truly,

J. G. Doughty.

P.S. While writing, there is another matter I would like to mention. I believe it will be my turn to attend the General Assembly, which will meet at Port Arthur next June. (at Mrs. Smith). To attend this meeting would necessitate the closing of the school for not less than two weeks. Can it be arranged, that if I go, the time be made up by opening school in the middle of August instead of Sept 1st?

J. G. D.
Ottawa, January 4, 1923.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, intimating your willingness to attend the Teachers' Summer School at the Agricultural College, Winnipeg, during the month of July. In May, next, you will please requisition, through the office of Mr. Agent Ogletree, for an advance of $50.00 in this connection. I am convinced that this summer school, while held primarily for teachers of public schools, will offer you real assistance in the matter of teaching methods for the Indian youth.

With reference to your wish to attend the General Assembly next June, favourable consideration will be given if you make your request to Mr. Agent Ogletree, early in May, next. He will forward the application to Ottawa and arrangements will be made, if our representative concurs, to close school early in June and to re-open on the 15th of August.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. J. A. Donaghy,
Teacher,
Swan Lake School,
Indian Springs, Man.
Ottawa, Jan. 8, 1923.

Sir:-

At the suggestion of the Provincial School Inspector, the Rev. J. A. Donaghy, Teacher of the Swan Lake Indian Day School, has intimated his willingness to attend the Teachers' Summer School at the Agricultural College, Winnipeg, during the month of July, next. We have informed Mr. Donaghy that the Department will make him an advance of $50 towards his expenses in taking the course, which advance will be deducted from his salary in four quarterly instalments during the school year 1923-24. When he completes the course, his salary will be increased to $950, from September 1, 1923.

Mr. Donaghy has been informed that he should requisition, through your office, for this advance of $50, in time to receive the same before he begins the course. When this request has been made by him, you will be good enough to forward it to the Department, and a cheque for the above amount will be sent.

You should forward the same to the Department, when, if you concur, leave will be granted to close the school early in June, on the understanding that the teacher will re-open on the 15th of August following, to make up for the time lost by him during his absence at the Assembly.

Toronto.

Dear Sir,

I am just writing a few lines to report on the progress on the Mission and to bring one or two things to your notice.

I am pleased to say that quite a change has come over the situation here during the past few years. When I took over the Mission scholars were few and the attendance low. Now the school is overcrowded, the average being about 27 or 28 out of 29 on the roll. A mid-day meal has to be prepared for the scholars, and while they were few in numbers, this work was not considered very difficult, but it had not been mentioned by the Indian Department as far as I know; at least nothing was said to me about it when I took over the Mission. Gradually the work progressed, the attendance increased until we reached the present overcrowded condition. This is an encouraging fact, but with the increased attendance has come additional work in preparing the hot meal. It now practically takes up all the forenoon of my wife's time cooking for them, that is, to such an extent that she cannot undertake any of her own household duties until afternoon.

Now the Indian Department has issued an order that she must bake bread for the school, and this to be used in place of the Government biscuits used up to now. This, added to the already increasing amount of work in connection with the feeding of the school is going to be quite a task, especially as we expect to have about 35 attending next winter. I spoke to the Agent a day or two ago about this he said the Department had nothing to do with arranging for the cooking of the meal, they simply supplied the material. I said that we had not been informed that this work had to be done at all.

My wife acts as Field Matron, and has charge of the medicines and also looks after the sick. This sometimes keeps her very busy, and with the increased amount of school work her duties will take up a great deal of her time. She receives a small allowance for this but quite a bit is paid out for horse hire in the winter; in the summer the car will run, but of course they do not run on air either. So I am writing to see if the Department made any arrangements with the committee about the school work, as it is not included in the work of the Field Matron.

I understand that at the Fairford school, the only other one serving dinner, they have put in a girl to do all the baking and cooking. Their attendance is about double ours; they have two rooms. My wife sometimes takes the big girls out of class to help prepare the meal so as to teach them, but does not care to use too much of their time in this way.

We are now waiting for word about the promised new school which will have to have a large class room, dining room, kitchen, cloak room and wash room. If we do not get a new building the present unsanitary conditions cannot produce proper results. I went into this fully in my last annual report and expect to hear about it soon. But the new school with its equipment for cooking and serving dinner for about 35 on an average will mean considerable more work. The meal will have to be cooked at the school and the cook will have to be there to look after things until all is cleaned up after dinner, so I feel that the Department should supply some help. It also looks as though it will be necessary to have someone to care for the new building, as it will have to be thoroughly cleaned every day. A big boy or girl could be allowed a little for this. I could do it myself and save the expense but my other work (Mission) would suffer, and besides it would not allow any time for business or work in connection with the mission.

You see our work is passing into a higher and more complicated stage, which is an encouraging feature, and I am writing this to acquaint you with this fact and the conditions arising from it, and also to ascertain if it is the Church or Department that makes the arrangements for preparing and serving the hot dinner.

The teaching part of the work has reached the point where there is no lost time, and I use everything I can to keep up interest and make study easy. This makes it more interesting to teach.

Yours truly,
Sgd. Jas. A. Donaghy

Dear Dr. Scott,

Enclosed please find copy of a letter I have received from Rev. J. A. Donaghy, our missionary at Swan Lake, Man. I am not sure that I am very familiar with the situation but I understand that in most of the Indian Day Schools the Government provides food for a hot meal at noon for the school children, and that two or three of the larger pupils, under supervision of the teacher or the matron, if one is employed by the Department, prepares this meal, and the children are taught to set the table, wash the dishes etc.

I believe that at Cote Indian School the Matron is employed by the Department and gives her whole time to this work and that Mrs. Marshall, the teacher, has been aiding the Matron.

We are delighted to hear of the progress of the work at Swan Lake and the close cooperation between Government officials and our Missionary and his wife has largely been instrumental in bringing this about. Three years ago this Reserve was reported to us as one of the most pagan. A remarkable change seems to have taken place.

To return to the Field Matron's duties, I do not see how she can do the work on the Reserve, visit the sick and dispense medicine, prepare the mid-day hot meals, bake the bread, teach the children etc. without more assistance. It must also be borne in mind that she is the Missionary's wife and in this capacity has countless other duties devolving upon her. I do not know how to overcome the difficulty. How would it be to give Mrs. Donaghy an increase in salary and let her secure her own assistance for this work?

Yours sincerely,

JHE/EB

Rev. J.H. Edmison, D.D.

Dear Sir:

The situation in connection with our day school at this mission is such that I find that unless something is done immediately the work will be severely handicapped.

The school is a one roomed building (downstairs) about 17'x26' inside. It is fitted with 30 single seats and we have 51 on the roll without counting my own two children which make 53, and the attendance is around 30 to 31. 9 of these sit at a table used for their mid-day meal, and 3 sit at another small table, and still another at my desk. Efficient teaching is impossible in such cramped quarters as it is impossible to take class up to the front for a blackboard lesson as the tables are there. Lack of room keeps everything in disorder as there is only room to hang a few coats or hats; the rest are deposited in a corner behind the rear seats. The porch is used as a washroom in the summer, but during the winter this very important part of our equipment has to be dispensed with for lack of space.

There being only table room for a few during the mid-day meal the rest are forced to use their desks, which become greased up when soup or meat is served. The desk tops slope and spilling is the usual thing with the little ones. This makes things far from sanitary, especially during the fly season. The teacher's desk has to be used for a side table.

The atmosphere of the room during the severe winter months becomes filthy because of lack of ventilation. Windows cannot be opened as they lift from the bottom and children sit right against them. This is hardly in keeping with what the Department considers a healthy environment. To talk on the value of fresh air in such a class room is very inconsistent.

Conditions have changed to such an extent that the present building is totally inadequate to meet our needs, so what will it be like next winter when more are attending if I take them in?

We are desperately in need of a building having the following accommodation:

1. Seats for 40 scholars.
2. Dining room in which to feed them.
3. Kitchen in which to prepare the meals.
4. Separate wash rooms and cloak rooms for boys and girls.
5. An adequate water supply. At present it is all carried from a well about 600 feet away.

6. Some arrangement for a supply of help in preparing the meals.

When we came here over three years ago it was not a very big task to prepare the meal for the 8 or 9 attending; but now the work has become so great that something must be done to supply help. The Department has ordered my wife to bake bread for this large group of children. (It must be kept in mind that she has her own baking to do also). This is no small extra to add to what she has been doing, and there is a limit to the amount of time she can spend upon such work. At Fairford day school a cook was put in, but of course their attendance is double ours. But ours is large enough to require that something be done. Either they should make it possible for my wife to hire someone to do her work, or hire someone to assist in the baking and cooking. To take the big girls from the morning class every day is too much. Cooking lessons are all right in their place, but they should not displace mathematics and reading.

At present the meal is prepared at the Mission House and carried over to the school more than 200 feet away. In a summer gale or winter blizzard this is not a pleasure. That is why I say the new school should have its own kitchen where the cooking can be done and the dishes washed and put away.

We have always had to supply the fuel for this small restaurant when our oil stove would have done our private cooking for the summer, but expensive fuel must be used every day because of the school.

You will see from these lines that something should be done this summer as more scholars are coming of age, and none will be leaving for a year at least, then we might lose four.

Hoping something will be done shortly, I remain

Yours truly,

Sgd- Jas. A. Doneghy
Duncan C. Scott, Esq., F.R.C.S., Litt.D.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Ottawa, June 9, 1924.

Sir:

I have to inform you that Mr. J. A. Donaghy, Teacher of the Swan Lake Indian Day School, has written to the Presbyterian Church Authorities, urging that provision be made to allow a development in the work. You will remember that in April of last year you recommended that a new school house be erected and that the old one be used for a dining room, washroom and cloak-room. There were so many pressing claims on the Appropriation for Indian Education, that the item in this connection was crowded out of our Estimates for this fiscal year; but I wish to inform you that the need at this school will not be overlooked as we are placing our requirements for next year before the Honourable the Superintendent General.

Mr. Donaghy reports that the preparation of the noonday meal for the pupils is becoming so onerous a duty that the field matron has very little of her time released for other work. It has been suggested that some assistance be given Mrs. Donaghy. Please let me have your recommendation in this connection.

The teacher reports that the field matron has been instructed to discontinue the serving of biscuits at noon and to bake bread. Please let me know if you have any knowledge of these instructions, as they do not appear to have been given by the Department. It may be that, if biscuits are issued and the field matron is empowered to take some of the older girls from the classroom to assist her, no further action will be necessary in connection with the preparation of the noonday meal.

The teacher states that he has had to supply the fuel needed for the preparation of the midday meal. The Department considers this a charge against Appropriation for Indian Education and you may instruct Mr. Donaghy to requisition to you for whatever is required for this purpose.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

In reference to your letter of the 9th instant, No.127-6-1. I beg to say that I cannot recommend any assistance being given to Mrs. Donaghy in preparing the noon day meals by the Department. If the work is too much for Mrs. Donaghy I would suggest that the appointment of Field Matron be discontinued, and have her devote her full time in preparing the noon meals.

In regard to the baking of bread, I did not instruct Mrs. Donaghy to discontinue the serving of biscuits. I told her what we were doing at the Fairford School, giving the children bread instead of biscuits, she asked me if she could bake bread for them. I informed her that she could bake the bread if she wished, as I told her the children looked under fed, it was her own suggestion to bake the bread.

I did instruct her to give these children milk instead of tea as I do not consider the children should use tea, we do not allow any tea in the other school.

Reverend Sir:

It is further suggested that Mrs. Donaghy utilize the services of the older girls to assist her in the cooking and serving of the meal. The older boys also might assist in the carrying of water and in the cleaning up after the meal.

Regarding the baking of bread, the agent states that he did not instruct Mrs. Donaghy to serve bread instead of biscuits. It was her own suggestion that she be allowed to bake bread. The quantity of biscuits contracted for to be delivered this school year for the fiscal year 1924-25 is 1000 pounds. The older girls would receive valuable training if they assisted in the preparing and serving of the food, and, if Mrs. Donaghy would utilize their services and the services of the older boys, there would not appear to be any need for hiring extra help.

The Department is aware of the lack of facilities at this school for the preparing and serving of the meal, also the need of more accommodation for classroom purposes. When our Estimates are being considered for the next fiscal year the needs at this school will not be overlooked. We hope that Mr. and Mrs. Donaghy will endeavour to carry on under present conditions until better facilities can be provided.

Sir:

There is a matter upon which I would like to have your ruling, although I regret having to do so.

Through what I considered lack of organization, some of the Indians left the Reserve to work outside. This left their own thrasher probably a little short. Now as the season is getting late, the Farm Instructor wished to release some of the men and help so they can plow and take my school boys to fill the gap. I have protested to him, claiming he as truancy officer has no right to do this, especially as we are taking up particular work with this class. He has plenty of man power at his disposal and I feel that he should use it and not my scholars. This reflects upon my work by reducing my average, as well as putting my high scholars behind in their work.

On account of the attitude Mr. Hillhouse has assumed I feel that we ought to have your ruling upon this. I can conceive of conditions in which it would be good to release some boys for a short time but not when members of the band are working outside the Reserve.

I regret that Mr. Hillhouse's attitude toward the Department's educational work here is not what I feel it should be. I was sorry to have to speak to you last summer about some work which he had promised to do many weeks before, but never found time to carry out. Also, it is now about fourteen months since you asked him to see that the lattice in front of the closets was painted. I was partly done, and since then I have only been able to get his assurance that he is going to do it. The unfinished job is very noticeable to visitors, and it reflects upon my ability to look after the premises and keep things neat. I would like to see it finished before another winter sets in. I am sorry to bring these things to your notice, but I do not like to see my end of the work used in this manner.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) Jas. A. Donaghy

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK. Oct. 27th, 1924

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am herewith forwarding a copy of a letter which I received from the Rev. James A. Donaghy, the school teacher on the Swan Lake Reserve. You will note that the gist of his complaint is that some of the Indians left the reserve this fall to work outside, and that the Indians being short handed on the reserve machine, some of the boys from the school were taken to help out with the work.

This man seems to be impossible to get along with. I have been on this reserve on several occasions and Mr. Hillhouse has done exceptionally good work since he went down there, as conditions on the reserve certainly show.

It is only natural that the Indians who do not have a crop would go off the reserve to work at threshing in order to make some money to provide for themselves and their families, and if the threshing machine on the reserve was short handed probably for a week or ten days I can find no fault with the Farming Instructor for keeping a few boys out of school to help out with the work. We all realize that while the weather is favourable the threshing must be pushed to the limit, and there is no doubt in my mind that the same thing is taking place in every white settlement in Western Canada, i.e., boys old enough to work are being kept out of school to help with the harvesting and threshing.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Last spring I wrote to you asking about the fuel used in preparing the mid-day meal for the children at the Swan Lake Indian School. You forwarded to me a copy of a letter sent to the Agent, Mr. A. Ogletree, in which he was instructed to ask me to requisition him for the necessary amount. As this was not done I wrote asking him if he knew anything about what should be done. I received no reply, but we went on using our own supply, thinking it would all be arranged later. I wrote again last week, and have just received word from him that he has no authority to purchase wood for the school.

Probably he has forgotten about the letter he received last June, or may have overlooked that paragraph.

Since school opened on Sept. 1st we have used quite a lot of fuel preparing daily dinners for about 30 children, as a big fire has to be kept going until the dishes are cleaned up after dinner. This increased fuel consumption about one third, we have judged. I do not like to remind the Agent that he has information about this matter, but as it is now four years since we began using our own wood, which is costing $6 a cord sawed (but not split) I think it is time the Department did something about it.

The paragraph in the letter to Mr. Ogletree from Mr. J. D. McLean reads as follows:

"The teacher states that he has had to supply the fuel needed for the preparation of the midday meal. The Department considers this a charge against Appropriation for Indian Education and you may instruct Mr. Donaghy to requisition to you for whatever is required for this purpose." (Dated June 9th, 1924).

I judge that the Department owes us around 15 cords for the four years, but I don't suppose they feel like making up for past years.

Yours truly,

(Signed) Jas. A. Donaghy.

I BEG TO SUBMIT THE FOLLOWING REPORT ON THE

YEAR ENDING MARCH 31st. 1926.

IN THESE AGENCIES THERE ARE THREE RESIDENTIAL
SCHOOLS, VIZ:-
PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE, PRESBYTERIAN.
SANDY BAY, ROMAN CATHOLIC.
PINE CREEK, ROMAN CATHOLIC.

THERE IS ALSO TEN DAY SCHOOLS, VIZ:-
EBB AND FLOW, FAIRFORD, LAKE MANITOBA.
LITTLE SASKATCHEWAN, LAKE ST MARTIN, PINE CREEK,
SWAN RIVER, SHOAL RIVER, WATERHEN. AND A SCHOOL HOUSE
AT ROSEAU RAPIDS this school has been closed several years.

Portage la Prairie, Agency.

SWAN LAKE DAY SCHOOL, is the only Indian day that is
now open in this Agency at the present time. This school
is run under the Presbyterian Mission and the teacher is
the Rev. J.A. Donaghy. There has been built by the Department
a fine New School during the year 1925 which is greatly
appreciated by the Indians of this Band, and it shows them
the interest the Department is taking in educating their
children and there is very little trouble in getting these
children to attend school regular. They are also supplied
with a mid-day meal which also encourages regular attendance
to pupils who live some distance from the school. This meal
is served under the supervision of Mrs. Donaghy, with one or
two of the elder girls to assist her. Mrs. Donaghy also
gives the Indian women and pupils lessons in cooking, baking,
sewing, knitting and other helpful work. There is a large
garden here and enough potatoes and other roots were grown
for the supply for the years mid-day meals. Progress is
reported of the pupils by the teacher, the school is kept
clean and the pupils are clean, happy and contented.
There are 31 children on the school Register with an average
attendance of 23.

UNITED CHURCH INDIAN MISSION.

INDIAN SPRINGS, Man.

December 17th/26.

Mrs. Chas. Clark,
Toronto.

Dear Mrs. Clark:

I am writing this in haste so as not to waste any time in getting it to you. Your letter arrived today, and at the same time we received two parcels of Xmas gifts for the children. One was a small box that came by mail, but it helps out the situation. The other was from Garden Hill, Ont., and had a few articles of clothing, but Xmas gifts from the young folks constituted the main bulk. We had a friend at Creemore, Ontario, who had sent out presents for two years, but they went against Union and of course could not help any more. But she has written saying that she spoke to the Erskine Church, Meaford, and they sent out the box by mail. Mrs. Ferguson of Creemore is very much interested in our work and is very sorry they are now separated from it. But she thinks the Meaford folks will take an interest in it now. The Garden Hill young people asked if they could be of any help, and I sent a reply in haste so their box came today. Then there is still a donation coming from Wawanesa, Man. It will be Xmas things. So though it looked discouraging only a week ago, it has brightened up suddenly as the Xmas season approaches.

Then, I must acknowledge the bale that came from Toronto a day or two ago. This is the bale that is going to make the little school children feel like enjoying the winter holidays. It contained warm stockings, underclothing, and quite an assortment of clothing. One thing we were pleased about in this, and that is that the boys have been looked after. The girls have been getting the big share of the clothing but the boys are now going to have their turn. We have one little fellow coming to school and he has not sufficient clothing to keep out the ordinary fall breezes. What he has is in rags. We have had a very cold spell of winter, and I believe the East has had some too. But out here it bites deep into the flesh, and can numb and freeze your face in a very short time.

This bale contained some very nice baby clothes, and there are babies here to use them. I think we have eight under a year old. Then the piece of canton flannel will be an good hands, as some of our women are very good with the needle. There were also twelve quilts, and the old folks have been coming frequently to see if we had anything to give them during the severe spell. I think some of them saw the bale at the station, for its arrival seems to be widely known already.

At present it must be quite a task for the United Church to carry on this work, as none of it has been handed over to the non-concurring congregations yet, and they are standing by doing nothing. It is too bad Mr. Okanase is acting as he is. We have some true friends there among those Indians, and they write to us. We are at present selling some
moccasins for three of the women who have a hard time making their own living. Our Indians here cannot get the leather, so we send up there for the moccasins. These people were the mainstay of the church there, and stood up against some of Joe Boyer's doings. They say they cannot get anything from Mr. Wilson, unless they pay for it. I have known him ever since he started in at College and never admired his character. The Antis expect to have the Birtle School and the three reserves up there, I should say four, as the Birdtail is there too.

Now I must close. I hope some of the worry will fall from your shoulders. We are in very fair shape now for Xmas. Some of the Indians gave a few dollars to buy things for their children.

The weather is trying to moderate a bit, and it will be a blessing to many on the prairie and in the city.

We thank you very much for the relief you have given us.

Yours truly,

(Signed) James A. Donaghy.
Duncan C. Scott, Esq., F.R.S.C.,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have yours of December 29th. in regard to Swan Lake. I have taken this up with Mrs. Clark of the Women's Missionary Society, and she has given me a copy of a letter she received recently from Mr. Donaghy. You will see that he has been selling "accessories" to some of the Indians. These were not sent forward by the Women's Missionary Society.

I expect that the complaint that has been sent in to you is just a continuation of the old anti-union propaganda which has been, and is still being conducted by some of the anti-union leaders.

With regard to the selling of supplies, I find this occurs only when there happens to be an over supply of articles. The old and needy are always cared for, but if there is an over supply and if there are some who can well afford to pay, the proceeds are used for some urgent needs of the school. If some of these Indian people can afford to pay there is no reason why they should be pauperized.

I trust this information will be sufficient.

Yours sincerely,

I am informed that Mr. Minielly, the farm instructor on the Swan Lake Indian reserve, Manitoba, is not satisfied to continue his duties, because of the attitude and actions of Mr. Donaghy, the teacher of the Swan Lake Indian Day School. You will remember that we have discussed Mr. Donaghy's case at different times and I believe it is now advisable for him to be transferred to some other work. I should be grateful if you would take steps to this end at an early date. Some time ago, the Department transferred the previous farm instructor because of difficulty with Mr. Donaghy, but I am now satisfied that this teacher must shoulder much of the responsibility as, apparently, none of our officers can work in harmony with him.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

The Superintendent General,

Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I wish to bring to your attention a situation which I feel should be looked into by the Department.

I believe you have received numerous reports from Mr. Ogletree, Agent at Portage la Prairie, reflecting upon my conduct here, and creating the impression that I am making trouble for the Farm Instructor. He has sent in a number of absolutely false statements which I feel it is my duty to have cleared up. He says he has sent in many, all equally untrue, I believe. I have been advised to ask the Department to look into these before taking any other action against Mr. Ogletree. Such charges are serious, and Mr. Ogletree should have enquired into them before sending them on as facts. I realize that the Department has a right to believe its representatives, and he has imposed upon this trust and made himself liable.

FIRST. He has accused me of trying to engage a lawyer to fight the Department in a liquor case. My record in the fight against liquor on this Reserve is not in keeping with such a statement, which is absolutely false. A family engaged a lawyer when the head of the house was sent to jail, and denied the right to secure a lawyer to defend him. So they claimed. The lawyer told me lately that he had a good case against the Department, but it would have cost the man too much to push it. And not until the other day did I know what was done about this matter, as I did not even ask the family what was being done. Mr. Ogletree must correct this matter.

SECOND. Mr. Ogletree has stated that I have been writing to the fur buyers of Brandon, and trying to make trouble between them and Mr. Minisilly. This untruthful report could only have its source in the mind of Mr. Minisilly who is primarily responsible for it.

On one occasion Mr. Minisilly cashed a fur check for an old man, and did not give him the full amount. The man asked me to phone the buyer and ascertain how much he should have received. The man did not say how much, but said it should have been more. He wrote to the Indian and told him to go to Mr. Minisilly and he would fix it up. He did so and received a few dollars more. Naturally, this set every tongue on the Reserve wagging, but I told the man that there must have been some good reason for what Mr. Minisilly had done. Please compare this with what Mr. Ogletree has said about the matter.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6248, file 544-1, part 1)
THIRD. I also understand that I am accused of being the author or instigator in the production of a letter recently sent to the Department, the letter being sent in the name of the Chief. The Agent tried to force the Chief to state that I was responsible, but in spite of all he said he stood by what is true. This letter was the sole production of the old men; they worked out among themselves at some time, I do not know when. They felt that things were being run in a strange manner here and so expressed themselves. When asked to produce proof of his contention Mr. Ogletree will find his position a difficult one.

FOURTH. Two school girls were absent for many weeks after Xmas, one was supposed to be sick, but was attending dances and picture shows. I asked the Farm Instructor, as Truancy Officer, to look into these cases. He refused to have the sick one examined to ascertain whether she was ill or not. I asked Mr. Ogletree why nothing could be done. He apparently ordered an examination then, and she was declared too sick for school. In replying he gave me what is termed a "bawling out" for complaining about the non-attendance of certain children, and trying to make trouble for Mr. Minielly, while he held reports showing they were too ill to attend. I replied that his statement could not be correct, as he held no report until I had insisted upon action being taken, and also he held such a report for ONE case, as the other was kept home to nurse the baby. I also told him I was doing what the Department insisted upon me doing, and embodying it in my annual report.

FIFTH. The school coal ran out very early this spring and I was forced to burn very small cook stove wood in the furnace. 8 tons should have been put in the bin last fall, but not over 6 were delivered. There was one ton on hand when the new arrived. The bin is 7 X 10 ft., and the coal averaged 4 ft deep, or 280 cu. ft. Call it 300 ft. The rule I used calls for 42 ft. for loose lumps, which proved correct in my own case where it was both weighed and measured.

I merely asked Mr. Ogletree what I would do in case of shortage. He questioned Mr. Minielly who reported that he delivered the 8 tons, which is positively incorrect, as that would have made 9 tons in the bin, only 4 ft. deep. 9 tons would have reached to the top of the door. The grain elevator at Indian Springs got a few tons out of this car, and Mr. Minielly has a large supply in his own bin. Mr. Ogletree gave me to understand that it was none of my business where the coal went. Perhaps he is right. If the Department is satisfied that 9 tons can be put in less than 300 cu. ft. all right, but I received 9½ tons and it occupied around 390 cu. ft. So I am reported for making trouble when I asked where our school coal went. I think the Agent should have made it HIS business to know where it went.

I believe a regular campaign of such material has been forwarded to the Department from time to time, some of which is of a much more serious nature than any I have mentioned, but all equally baseless. As I believe this has resulted in real damage being done to my reputation, and to my home, and my ability to act fair and above board in my work, I must ask that Mr. Ogletree be requested to
do something immediately to remedy the situation ha has produced, I have been advised to try and have this settled within the Depart-
ment, but failing in that I will have to resort to other means. The Department refused to let me take an appointment in the east, showing conclusively that the false statements sent in by the Agent have done real harm, the value of which will have to be estimated.

The Farm Instructor seemed to be indifferent to everything but his salary check. The young men wanted leadership, and he failed in what was a supreme opportunity to do something substantial in moulding their opinions. The old men wanted guidance, and got none. I did all I could for them, and it remains to be proven that my influence has done harm. The Agent has wielded the "big stick" over the Chief and Councillors, and forbade them signing any letter to the Depart-
ment. With them gagged and me out of the way, many irregularities can be put through. The old men wrote the letter mentioned because things are not what they should be. They blame the Instructor for much of it, including the loss of a large number of cattle last win-
ter through lack of supervision. Mr. Ogletree says I have been "inter-
fering with all the farm instructors we have had there during the last few years". There was only one other, Mr. Ogletree's action put him out. The Indians feel that an Instructor should be able to teach them, and this man had to bring in another to run a very small thresh-
er last fall, at a cost of $10 a day, so they say. The Indians ran their old big outfit several years when there was no Instructor here. So they look for someone better than themselves, and I feel that he should measure up to their expectations. But it is not my place to criticise him. The Department has concluded that I am unsuited to take charge of an Indian School, and that decision is based upon untruthful reports sent in by the Agent. Only a complete correction, and restoration of my standing will clear the matter up. I trust the Department will see that this is done.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

Your letter of June 27th came to hand, but I was unable to give it attention until now. It is in answer to one from me asking that your Agent at Portage la Prairie be requested to retract certain false and damaging statements which he sent in to your Department. You refer to these as "misunderstandings". If that were all they were I would let them pass unnoticed, but they are not, but are statements sent in for the purpose of damaging my record in the eyes of the Indian Department. Evidently he succeeded in doing this as you refused to allow me to take an appointment in the east. I intend to take action against your Agent for sending in falsehoods concerning the work done at the Swan Lake School unless I have definite word from you that these have not injured me in the eyes of the Department. I would be very sorry to hear that the Department supported Mr. Oglethorpe in this despicable piece of work, and naturally, in a court action, the Department's conduct towards a Missionary-teacher, as reflected through an Agent in the mental and physical condition of Mr. Oglethorpe, would create a very unfavorable impression. For at least three years he has been unfit to have charge of such an important position.

Will you kindly let me know if I am now ruled out of ever being permitted to teach in an Indian School. I have accepted my present charge as a temporary arrangement, as my interest in the Indians has not been dropped.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 2nd, with reference to the work done by Mrs Cooper during the school year.

In confirmation of our conversation in the Agency Office on this matter, I would advise you that no funds are at our disposal for paying Mrs Cooper for her work, and that work of the same nature is done by all wives of Missionaries in this Agency, without pay.

I would suggest that the girls between the ages of 11 and 14 years be taught this work, under the supervision of Mrs Cooper, as knowledge of this nature would be very useful after they leave school. I think that once the girls have been taught to cook and wash, they would take sufficient pride in their work to carry on with very little supervision.

With reference to the meals cooked for 20 other persons, doing work around the school and grounds, I presume this work was authorized by the Department, and sufficient funds would be estimated for to cover all expenditure in connection with the work, and bills should have been forwarded covering this item.

I appreciate the good work Mrs Cooper is doing, and regret that you did not look into this matter before accepting the appointment, as your predecessors will have done the same work for about two years without any financial assistance. Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the various schools in the Portage la Prairie and Manitowah Agencies. This report was made by Mr. Inspector Hamilton, who was occupied from the 25th February to the 11th April in making an inspection of these two agencies.

Everything at the Swan Lake Indian Day School seems to be in a most satisfactory condition. The Inspector makes the usual comment regarding the children not speaking out distinctly. Conditions at the Waterhen Day School also appear to be fairly satisfactory.

At the St. Andrews Day School the Inspector points out that the attendance is irregular and progress slow. I am afraid the trouble here is that the Department have not the right kind of a man teaching the school, and it has occurred to me that it might be a good plan to suggest a change of teachers and also to issue instructions to have the children who are not attending school regularly sent to Boarding School. Those who belong to the Church of England might be sent to Elkhorn, and the two Roman Catholic boys mentioned could go to Lebret. In the case of Moses Cook it is pointed out that he has scarcely attended school at all during the past year.

With reference to the Ebb and Flow Day School, I would draw your attention to what the Inspector has to say regarding the teacher, Mr. Taggart.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

-The Inspector-
The Inspector points out that the Lake Manitoba Day School was closed on the day prior to Good Friday. I do not know why this should be. The attendance here is fair. The Inspector points out that while the teacher is qualified, he is of the opinion that a married man could fill this position much better. I do not know that I can agree with him in this. We have had some splendid results with two girls working in these schools, in fact better than when we had a man. We have nothing in the estimates to provide for repairing the interior of this school. I note the Inspector states that a large patch of plaster has fallen off the ceiling and more is loose.

The Lake St. Martin Day School was closed at the time the Inspector made his visit, as also was the Little Saskatchewan Day School.

The Fairford Improved Day School seems to be doing good work. There is nothing in connection with this institution that requires any special attention from the Department.

The Portage la Prairie Residential School is up to its usual standard, and good work is being done. The Inspector points out that the walls are cracked in places, and the plaster is lifting from the lath, due to a leaky roof which allows the rain to penetrate. There is nothing in the estimates for repairs excepting $400.00 to repair the verandah. Part or all of this amount might be used to repair the roof, as it is more important that the roof be cared for than the verandah, if only one of the two jobs can be done.

The Pine Creek Residential School is giving splendid satisfaction, and the children are well cared for.

The Inspector reports that the classrooms in the Sandy Bay Residential School were tidy and well aired, and the children clean. The building is not in good shape, and I would hesitate to spend much money on it. In the first place the school is not in a good location in my opinion.

On the whole I would say that the report on these schools is very satisfactory.

Yours very truly,

M. Graham

Dear Mr. Hoey,

During the early part of July I had the pleasure of visiting at the home of my friend, Mr. D.F. MacKenzie, M.P. Neepawa. We talked over certain educational problems. Since then I have been thinking over the work on this Reserve and in accordance with instructions of your letter of January 16th, 1937, I beg to make the following suggestions.

1. No children should be allowed to go to Portage school from this Reserve while there is room for them in this day school. Also children should attend here until a written statement has been received from the Agent transferring them to another school.

2. All half-breed children living on the Reserve should attend the school on the Reserve and not be sent to Portage.

3. A daily hot meal be provided in the day school (and not just for about three months) during the whole school year.

4. A reasonable amount of good milk be provided daily for the school children, not canned or evaporated milk.

5. Arrangements be made for the bigger girls to be taught how to prepare, cook, and serve meals. Also how and why wash dry and iron various articles used such as towels, etc.

6. A janitor to look after cleaning the school and fires.

I might say, that 3, 4 and 5 used to be carried out here. Mrs. C. was given a little allowance to do that work, and on the morning of every school day, some girl was given individual instruction in this kind of work. Two tons of coal were supplied for the year for this work and a number of the Indians told Mrs. C. that they were glad their girls were getting this kind of teaching.

I estimate the above cost would be around $400.00 for the year and in my opinion would be well worth while.

Yours obediently,

Sir,

Re file No. 127-6-1.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 17th ultimo with enclosed list of suggestions sent to the Department by the Rev. J.E. Cooper, teacher at the Swan Lake Day School. I have considered the proposals set out in Mr. Cooper's letter, and beg to report as follows:

1 and 2. I think Mr. Cooper's suggestion, especially in connection with the half-breed's, is unfair. There are two half-breed families on the Reserve, and the elder children in both cases have been through the Portage la Prairie Residential School. The families are named Swain and McKenny. The Swain family lives three miles from the Day School, is poorly clothed, and not fit to walk the three miles to school during the winter months. All the Swain children have been educated at the Portage la Prairie School and applications have recently been received for the admittance of the two younger children. I think that Mr. Cooper's suggestion refers especially to these children.

3. A daily mid-day meal is provided in all schools in this Agency where a Day School is situated during the winter months. The cooking of this meal is done by the teacher with the assistance of the older girl pupils. The materials for the meal are purchased by the Department and the service for cooking is given without cost and with pleasure by the teacher.

4. Mr. Cooper has a cow, and previous to the shipping of condensed milk with the mid-day meal supplies, used to sell milk for the meal, and this was paid by the Department. In discussions with various Medical Officers I am informed that condensed milk is purer and better for Indian children.

5. No mention is made in this paragraph of knitting and sewing. Only the serving and preparing of meals and washing and drying the articles used. This is also done at other Day Schools, the necessary washing of pots and pans being done after the meal is finished, and this again without cost to the Department.

6. This matter was taken up in my report of April 21st last, which was in answer to Department letter 14-127 of April 17th.

In making a general survey of all the suggestions embodied in Mr. Cooper's letter, the one fact is obvious, he is trying to augment his salary by being paid for work that other teachers do, gratis. Mr. Cooper is the best paid teacher in the Agency and does no other service but teach school.

Dear Mr. Cooper:

May I refer to departmental letter of August 17th, in which the statement was made that the suggestions contained in your letter of August 10th had been submitted to the Indian Agent for the district for his consideration and recommendation.

The Agent, in his report to the Department, states that only the children of certain half-breed families who live a considerable distance from the day school have been sent to the Portage la Prairie institution. I make this statement as an illustration of how difficult it is to make certain adjustments that on the surface may appear comparatively simple.

I feel confident you will experience no difficulty whatever in reaching an agreement with the Agent whereby the senior girls can be given a certain amount of instruction in cooking and in the serving of meals. My own opinion is that these girls should do all the work in connection with the noonday meal. Dear Mr. Cooper,

According to the nurse's of the Swan Lake Reserve, there are three new cases of Trachoma.
