Dear Mr. Hoey,

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 15th ultimo. May I place a few facts before you. Enclosed sheet number 1 shows the various items of provisions used for a hot lunch at this day school for each year from 1927-1928 to the present day. The total amount is estimated as I do not know the price of biscuits supplied. For the first years the prices of the other items are made from a copy of the bills paid. You will notice that in 1927-1928 the estimated value of provisions used was $264-57. This fall we started school with 24 boxes of biscuits. The Agent in 1927 told us that it had been found necessary to supply a hot mid-day lunch to the school children.

A study of sheet number 1 tells its own tale, and further comment is hardly necessary. However, I would like to point out that these children who stay on the Reserve and come to school here should have as good a consideration given to them as the children who go away to Portage. I could point out many advantages that these children do enjoy, but there are some that should come through the day school.

May I point out also, in accordance with instructions received in Winnipeg Normal School, I have each year made out a list of children of school age, and I have taken an interest in their attendance. When children have not been at school, I have visited their homes and while I have found some, I have also found that some were reported sick, but were away running around the country. In this connection I have found that in trying to get them to come regularly to school, they have, i.e., the parents have resisted my enquiries. Of course all teachers are up against this kind of proposition. My actions along this line were successful during the first years, but now are not so successful. I enquire and try to persuade the parents to send their children, and it is left there, as that seems to be the only way out of the difficulty for me. Parents are able to tell me what they can do with their children.

In the question of attendance I find that the half-breed children and those of U.S. Ancestry, give the greatest amount of trouble. John McKinney, is a Canadian half-breed, and a very good worker. His children were coming very irregular although they have only a little over 1½ miles to come to school. Mike Swain, a U.S. Half-breed, has given a lot of trouble. He lives a little over 2½ miles from this school and a little over 1½ miles from a provincial public school. His children were taken by Mr. Jones to Portage on the 31st. of August.

A couple of weeks ago some of our Indians were over to Portage and were at the school. Mr. Jones told them that he had 92 children in school and could not take any more. He also
I understand that Mr. Jones paid you a visit. I wish I had at my disposal the funds similar to his, then I could pay you a visit and put before you the claims of the children of this Reserve, who, in my opinion are not receiving anything like the help that the Portage school is getting. I think it is very unfair for any principal of a school to come on this Reserve and take children from it without talking the matter over with the resident teacher. May I point out to you that Mrs. C. and I have been on this Reserve over 10 years. We know something of human nature and we do know a little about these people here.

Ever since there was a school on this Reserve till 1932 there has always been a hot lunch provided for the children. As stated in my letter of the 10th of August the older girls were given instruction by Mrs. C. along that line. You also think that such instruction is invaluable. The work was done by the older girls but instruction was not given by me. The children will not work to any advantage unless there is some one older with them. I know why this mid-day lunch did not meet with the approval of Mr. Waitz.

As regards the milk supply. When we first came here we were told to spend £40 per day on milk. We had considerable trouble in getting milk that satisfied us. However in January 1932, to make sure we bought a cow ourselves and supplied milk to the school. The barn is kept clean and often disinfected, the cow is government tested, I do the milking and Mrs. C. washes the milking utensils. This was done primarily so that the children could have good milk to drink. Of course secondary, the milk clause at the end of the month was welcome. We bought hay from the Indians and thus helped them. We could supply milk if necessary.

I wrote to my friend Mr. F.D. MacKenzie because as a teacher he would understand. He saw you and read portions of my latter to you. Apparently you promised him that some things would be done. For example an allowance for janitors' work would be made, some ploughing would be done, and so forth. Not one thing...
I suggested a janitor in my letter of August, I did not desire to state the reason for this. On June 9th, 1928, Mr. Christianson with Mr. Waits as the newly appointed Agent paid Treaty in the school house. After the payment, the then Clerk, Mr. Burton, (now deceased) with Mr. Christianson's instructions paid me two dollars so that I could get some Indian woman to clean the school. Of late Mr. Waits has used the school house, and it has been left in a very different state from what he got it. In the cloak rooms there were much spitting on the floor and on the school room floor there was much of tobacco remains and many used matches. I have had to clean this mess up a number of times and I object to it, but the Agent pays no attention to my objection.

On the back of school registers supplied, it states that the floors are to be frequently washed. When I started on this job, the first time the then Agent visited the school, I asked him about this. His reply was that the school floors washed every two weeks. I have carried out my instructions along that line to the best of my ability. The last time I had it cleaned was on the 19th. of June last. At the end of June I sent the original receipts to Portage Indian Office, and at the end of September I put in a bill for same. Up to the time of writing I have not received payment for this account.

In the spring the boys and I dug the ground for the potato crop. We looked after it, and at the end of March and again at the end of June I requisitioned paris green or arsenate of lime. During July I bought some at my own expense and my boy and I dusted the potato crop and thus saved it, with the result that we got more than two large barrels full of potatoes. I have not yet received any of these articles.

For a number of years I have requisitioned a buck saw. Two loads of poplar poles were delivered this last spring. We have used my buck saw till one day last week it was broken. I certainly would like it replaced and also one for the school. How can we get firewood for the school? The axe needs sharpening and is not in very good shape. I suppose my axe can be used till it gets out of commission.

We are 6½ miles away from Swan Lake village. For a number of years I have been allowed to get our supply of coal for the house along with the school supply. Last year it was sent in from Portage a distance of about 70 miles with track. I was not told anything about it coming and I found myself in the position of being almost frozen in with no fuel supply. Common courtesy would seem to suggest that I should be informed that I would have to make arrangements for our supply. Then again 4 tons of the 10 tons supplied to the school were left out on the ground, some of the boys and I shovelled it into the coal bin. This year it will stay outside as far as I am concerned.

I have seen that the school was warm for 9 o'clock in the morning. I have also scrubbed the toilets myself so that they could be clean and sanitary. I shall see that the fires do not go out but I feel inclined not to get up around 7 A.M. in the winter to do it and I certainly am cutting out cleaning the toilets.

Will you please read sheets 2 to 9 and inform me what to do? I have a wife and boy and I certainly desire to do my best, but it appears to be more difficult each year, especially as your best efforts seem to be disparaged. Last year I looked after the equivalent of 1448 persons for trachoma and this...
This year 1542 persons so far.

The enclosed pictures were taken on the 10th. and 11th. of Sept. Pictures 1 and 2 are of trees on the Mission grounds that were planted on the 12th. of May 1932. Those of 3 and 4 were planted on the school grounds on the 11th. of May 1932 and are about 100 yards from those shown in pictures 1 and 2. I have asked and requisitioned for Indian help to keep these trees clean but these requests were granted and as we have not many boys we could not keep the trees clean.

I hope this letter will not weary you, but I would like to see this school in better shape.

Mrs. C. will be glad to help the girls and I would be pleased to give the bigger boys some instruction along manual training in woodwork, but arrangements would have to be made for the other children to be either kept at work or sent home. This would mean the school would have to be supplied with at least two outfits of woodwork tools. Also some wood would be needed.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Jos. E. Cooper

Dear Mr. Cooper:

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant and to thank you for the information contained therein.

The children of American Indians who may be living on the Swan Lake reserve from time to time are subject to the same laws insofar as attendance at school is concerned as Canadian Indians and the law in their case should be enforced.

I am not at all sure however that these American Indians have any actual rights on the reserve. It might be well if you secured definite information with respect to the number of these Indians, the length of time they have resided on the Swan Lake reserve and the names of the reserves to which they may be nominally attached in the United States. The whole question should then be submitted to the Superintendent of Reserves and Trusts for a ruling. In the meantime and until such a ruling is received by you, their children should be encouraged to attend school regularly.

The records here indicate that the attendance at the Swan Lake Indian Day School is in no sense satisfactory. This attendance has been irregular and somewhat unsatisfactory for two or three years. In view of the war conditions now confronting us, however, a sincere attempt is being made by the Department to encourage more regular attendance at our Indian day schools throughout the Dominion.

I have been wondering if it would be possible for you to take a personal interest in this matter and interview the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Residential School in respect to conditions on the Swan Lake reserve. The Principal of the Portage School, Mr. Jones, is constantly requesting an increase in pupilage at the Portage institution, while the records here indicate that he has at least 31 pupils enrolled at his school from the Swan Lake reserve. In other words, he is asking for an additional pupilage while the Swan Lake school is experiencing the utmost difficulty in securing a satisfactory attendance of pupils. It has occurred to me that it might be possible for the Principal at Portage la Prairie to return to the reserve a half dozen or so pupils who come from Indian homes where conditions are reasonably satisfactory. This matter has been discussed very fully with a representative of the United Church; the church authorities feel that some adjustment should be possible between the Principal of the Portage school and the teacher in charge of the Indian school at Swan Lake. There is not even a remote possibility that we can increase the pupilage at Portage la Prairie at any time in the immediate future, nor is there in my judgment a remote possibility that we shall have funds sufficient to buy the Principal at Portage la Prairie the additional lands that he has been anxious to secure during the last year or two.

You might, at your convenience, discuss this matter with the parties concerned and with Indian Agent Waite and let me have any recommendations you may care to send forward.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

The presbytery of Carman appointed a Commission to investigate conditions on the Indian Springs Reserve in so far as these conditions affected our Missionary and his work there.

At our September meeting the commission reported and the report was left in the hands of the executive which was charged with the responsibility of putting it in shape and of forwarding the resolutions arising out of the report to the proper authorities.

I am therefore forwarding to you the following resolutions:

(1) "That whereas we find that the School Attendance Act is not being enforced on the Indian Springs reserve to the extent that in our judgment it should (out of a possible attendance of 29, there is an average attendance of eleven) we respectfully suggest that more definite action be taken by your department to ensure a fuller compliance with the Indian Act regarding school attendance. We further suggest that the attendance enforcement officer should be in much closer touch with the school than it is possible for the R.C.M.P., who lives thirty miles distant, to be.

(2) That whereas we find that Trachoma and other diseases are prevalent on the Reserve and whereas we know that one lad living in the Floral School District contracted Trachoma as a result of coming in contact with children from the Reserve and whereas we understand that the inspection of the school by a Medical Officer has been discontinued, we suggest that medical inspection be restored and that action be taken to safeguard the white people living adjacent to the Reserve from the ravages of these diseases.

(3) That whereas we understand that many of the children on the Reserve are undernourished and whereas we know that the serving of a hot lunch at noon has been discontinued, we suggest that your Department should serve a hot noon-day lunch in the school and thus bridge the gap between the treatment of children in the residential schools and those in the day schools."

General comment: I hereby submit my annual report on Swan Lake Reserve (Day) School. I spent Nov. 21st in this school examining the work of the students and the teaching methods of Mr. J. E. Cooper, M.A., B.D. This is Mr. Cooper's thirteenth year on this reserve. During this time he has served the Reserve well and faithfully but it would appear that during the last year or so some misunderstanding has arisen between him and the Church Officials. In late October of this year a Commission was appointed by the Church to investigate all matters pertaining to the church. Mr. Cooper was kind enough to allow me to see a copy of this report. I think the report is a very comprehensive one and very fair in every respect. Mr. Cooper told me last year that he would like to be transferred to a new field and from what I was able to observe and from what he told me it is my opinion that this might be in the best interests of all concerned. I certainly think that this matter should receive the attention of the proper authorities before the close of the next school term. There are a number of factors which enter into this case and which do not concern me as an Inspector of Schools but as I have previously mentioned I feel that it would be in the best interests of everyone if a change were made.

(over)

N.B.—ONE FORM TO BE USED FOR EACH CLASSROOM TEACHER.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6248, file 544-1, part 2)
The students of this Reserve are not attending school in the way that they should and evidently no pressure is brought to bear upon them to do so. You will note that the enrolment speaks for itself and I might refer you to my report of last year which gives some indication of the attendance. I have singled out for this report two examples, such as that of student Mimir Tukumum, born 1925, attended school for the first time in 1932 and has attended a total of 32 days up to and including Nov. 21/39.

Also the case of her sister Dorothy Tukumum, born 1929, attended school in 1936 and has a grand total of 27 days up to and including Nov. 21/39.

There is also a student born 1932 who has not attended and a Walker family of five, ranging between the ages of 7 and 15, not attending school at all.

Mr. Cooper states that when he first took over this school, a number of years ago, he received a larger allowance to provide food and clothing and, of course, this was an attraction in itself to attend more regularly. Since the early days this has been reduced to practically nothing and at the present Mr. Cooper is trying to get by by serving them one light, warm lunch which consists of a bowl of soup and a couple of biscuits.

Mr. Cooper has another complaint to make and that is that the pupils are not getting the medical attention they deserve. Trachoma is very prevalent on this Reserve and there are few families, if any, not affected by this dread disease. This is also a matter which I feel deserves the immediate attention of the authorities.

GROUNDS.

Comparing pictures taken then and now, one would not recognize the grounds today from that of 12 years ago. Mr. Cooper has worked wonders in planting trees, shrubs and grasses. The fences and playground equipment are in very good shape.

BUILDINGS.

The outside buildings have received attention prior to the opening of school for this term and there is no criticism to be levied in this regard.

FLAG.

The flag is in good shape but requires a new rope. This needs immediate repair.

ROOM EQUIPMENT.

The library, Geography equipment, Music (Organ) and general supplies are very good. This year, I am sorry to say, I must report that there is no fire extinguisher or any kind.

SCHOOL HOUSE.

The school was redecorated last year. The exterior was painted during the summer of 1938 and the interior was redecorated during the Christmas Vacation. The seating, heating, lighting and ventilation is very good. The blackboards are the same as last year and range from good to poor. One piece of board will soon have to be replaced. The basement is very neat and tidy and it is here that the lunch is served and wood-working classes held. The students did not make as much progress in this particular field of work as they might have done. It is my opinion that in all these schools they should be given the opportunity to turn as much with their hands as possible. In the general classroom work I have found all the note books of the students very neat. Mr. Cooper does not allow them to keep many scribblers as he believes this to be in their own advantage due to the amount of Trachoma. The number work, writing and spelling is good, the reading fair. From my report you will note that the students are not graded higher than Grade V but I found one doing writing, spelling and some composition equivalent to Grade VII or VIII standing. The teaching of history, grammar, and geography seems to be a difficult matter.
I might add here that if a change is made in the teacher of this school this year an effort should be made to engage a good Primary teacher.

In closing I would like to pay a special compliment to Mrs. Cooper for the work that she has done in the interests of the girls of the Reserve.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge your letter 127-6-1, dated November 9th and to report that in company with Agent Waite, I investigated the complaints registered by the Carman Presbytery and would report on each resolution as follows:

1. The roll calls for 24 pupils. There are 5 children living over 2 miles from school. One child, Alexander Esquash, age 9, has enlarged glands and is in poor health. These facts naturally affect the attendance as often the Indian children have not the warm clothing required. Then again there are 7 children from American parents, 3 of which have not yet attended this term. These Indians live on the Reserve but are not members of the Band. Does section 10 of the Indian Act apply to the American children? I am of the opinion they should abide by the regulations or move off the Reserve. The balance of the children enrolled attend fairly well. Children who must continually be compelled to attend school, I fear, will make little progress. I am sure if the school life, and lessons, were made more attractive we would have less trouble.

2. This paragraph is somewhat misleading. Mr. Cooper explains that when he first took charge here the local doctor examined all school children in September and again in June. This practice has been discontinued. However we now have a nurse who visits the reserve quite often and new cases without spending some time at the school and especially attending to all the trachoma cases. We have a good medical officer and he comes to the Reserve when required. Dr. Wall has visited here and, I believe, intends doing so again this fall. In my opinion, these people receive good medical supervision.

3. The following food is supplied for a noon meal: Barley, rice, beans, oatmeal, 1 bushel of onions, 1 bushel of potatoes, cocoa, canned milk, biscuits and meat for boiling. This can be prepared in the school basement and cooked on the school range, if the teacher so desires. I am not at present prepared

In conclusion, I would like to say that I believe the Presbytery investigation was brought about by Mr. Cooper who, in my opinion, is disgruntled and dissatisfied, perhaps not without cause, yet as the result of the following accumulated circumstances. He points out that 14 years ago when he took charge, he received from the Department, in addition to his salary, two tons of coal which was used in his home for cooking the children's noon meal. His wife received $15.00 per month for her trouble. He also sold milk to the Department for the children at 5¢ per quart, from his cows which pastured on the Reserve. These extras have, in my opinion, rightly been discontinued. The noon meal can be cooked in the school basement on our own range. Teachers all across Manitoba do this work free and express delight and appreciation when food is supplied. In addition to all these changes, Mr. Cooper states that at first he received, from the Church, $700.00 per year plus his house. Now he receives $50.00 per year and house—certainly a drastic reduction.

Mr. Cooper stated he had written the Church officials stating that he feels his period of usefulness, at this point, has expired and he would like to be transferred to some other place. I think Mr. Cooper is quite sincere but, as pointed out above, circumstances have made him dissatisfied and, in my opinion, a dissatisfied man cannot render efficient service. I think, for all concerned, the Church would be well advised to favorably consider Mr. Cooper's request for a change to take effect June 30th, 1940.

My dear Mr. Hoey:

I have your letter of June 11th, in which you say that, in view of our representations in regard to salary, you will recommend that Mr. Ebbert be paid at the rate of $100.00 a month. While, of course, this is better than the $80.00 a month previously suggested, it does not meet the situation. What bothers me is that the Government and the Department feel free to make changes, not only in the amounts paid for salaries of the day school teachers, but in the per capita grants to the Indian Residential schools, without any consultation at all with the Church.

As I understand it, the Churches and the Government carry on this educational work together - at least so far as the residential schools are concerned - on the basis of an agreement adopted some years ago. We nominate teachers after we have told them what the salary paid by the Government is. They are willing to accept on these terms. Then, like a bolt from the blue, we hear from the Department that a change has been made in the salary. It seems to me that even in war time, an agreement is an agreement, and before it can be changed, both parties should be consulted and should be satisfied. While we recognize the financial difficulties faced by your Department, the Board of Home Missions of the United Church has financial difficulties too, and it seems to me that it is hardly treating us fairly to make arbitrary changes in amounts previously granted by a mere notice, such as has been given. It does not seem that the Churches, which put very large amounts into Indian education, have received quite the consideration which they deserve.

I want to be quite frank in letting you know how we feel about the way in which these reductions have been made. You will doubtless hear from the representatives of all the Churches later on.

I should like to add that we are grateful for the extra $10.00 a month for the Swan Lake School.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a report on the Swan Lake Indian Day School, dated November 8, 1940, sent forward by Inspector W. S. Lockhart.

I was disturbed to learn that there were only five pupils in attendance at this school at the time of the Inspector's visit. You can readily understand that it is not the policy or intention of the Department, in a critical period such as the one in which we find ourselves, to keep schools open and in operation with an attendance of five Indian pupils. As a matter of fact, we have refused to open a number of seasonal schools in the outlying districts of the Dominion, for the simple reason that the enrolment, in our judgment, did not justify us in operating such schools during the war period. I should add, however, that at several of these schools the enrolment was higher than it appears to be at Swan Lake.

It was my understanding last year that what was needed at Swan Lake was a change of teachers and the representatives of the United Church were disposed to agree with me. Consequently, Mr. Cooper was transferred to another appointment and Mr. T. W. Ebbern, B.A., was appointed to take charge at Swan Lake. Mr. Ebbern is paid salary from this Department at the rate of $100 per month and is, no doubt, made an allowance by the Home Mission Board of the United Church. I am interested of course only in the work of the school and I should like to have a report indicating the number of children of school age on the Swan Lake Reserve, who are within walking distance.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 23rd instant, in which you seek information with respect to certain so-called American Indians and half-breeds, residents of the Swan Lake Indian Reserve.

The records here indicate that the Department explained rather fully the position of American Indians resident on Canadian reserves, in a letter to Indian Agent Waite dated February 8, 1939. There is nothing on file, however, to indicate that the Indian Agent replied to that particular letter. American Indians living on the Swan Lake Reserve are subject to all the laws and regulations governing Canadian Indians. In a strictly legal sense we cannot exercise the same authority with respect to half-breeds. However, my personal opinion is that these half-breed children should be compelled to attend school regularly or be expelled from the reserve. The whole matter of half-breed children living on the Swan Lake Reserve is one that might very well be discussed with the Superintendent of Reserves and Trusts.

It would appear that we have at this date a large number of Canadian Indians living in the United States. This is particularly true of American territory immediately south of the province of Alberta. These Canadian Indians have never been denied access to the United States and have enjoyed over a period of years the right to attend American educational institutions. The privilege of attending an educational institution in the United States is also extended to Canadian Indians such as the Indians of the Caughnawaga Reserve, who visit the United States periodically and who, it would appear, live in that country for periods of two or three months each year. This is a somewhat delicate matter and you can readily understand how important it is that we should extend to the few American Indians living in this country all the rights and privileges extended to our own Indians. Should the number of American Indians in Canada increase substantially at any time, it is not possible the whole matter might have to be reviewed in the light of such an event. In the meantime, however, you should inform Indian Agent Waite that American Indians on the Swan Lake Reserve are subject to the same rules and regulations as the ordinary residents.

Dear Sir:

Swan Lake Indian Day School - Portage Agency.

I inspected this school December 10th. The teacher in charge is Mr. Shellenberg. The Roll calls 22 pupils and 19 were present. The grades are arranged as follows.

Grade 1 - 13  
2 - 4  
3 - 2  
4 - 2  
6 - 1

The average attendance for October was 20, Nov. 19, and December should reach 20 or 21.

Mr. Shellenberg in my opinion is a splendid teacher. He is full of life and energy and has a bright and pleasing personality. The children appear greatly interested, and if we are fortunate in keeping Mr. Shellenberg, I think our problem of attendance will be at best partially solved.

The lessons are made interesting and games are played during recess and at the noon hours. A hot lunch of soup is prepared and served by Mrs. Shellenberg. Next year the teacher plans a school garden so that vegetables will be available for the children's meal. The pupils will assist the teacher in planting and caring for the garden and in fall the vegetables will be stored for winter use.

The pupils were fairly well dressed and were neat and clean.

Some of the children have to walk two and three miles, and this is a long distance when the snow is deep and the weather very cold. However, I feel the children will now attend fairly well because school life has been made bright, happy, and interesting.

The school building is in good repair. The furnace grate is broke, but this is to be welded during the holidays.

Yours very truly,

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st, 1945.

Agriculture.

The early snow hung well on summerfallows until December. Then high wind swept them clear and there is some blowing of topsoils. Practically all surplus grains have now been hauled to elevators and sufficient seed if retained for the 1946 crop acreage. All rentals are now completed as far as the Department share of crop is concerned, and all leases have been checked are found still in force. One Indian, a returned veteran, would like to take over Indian Garden Reserve and farm both quarters, now rented to Buxton and Metcalfe for another year, February 1947, and farm it with the help of a loan under the Veterans' Land Act, given recently to Indians. A separate report will be forwarded to the Department on this matter as soon as the feelings concerning this matter have been ascertained. There does not appear to be any active opposition at the present time. Two veterans will be making application for the V.L.A. loan in the near future. Both will farm on the Swan Lake Reserve. The snow of November 9th and 10th stopped all work on the land. This snow came very early, soon after the completion of threshing and little or no fall plowing was accomplished. This leaves a lot of spring plowing to be done for coarse grain crops. Still plenty of potatoes among certain Bands. There are approximately 300 bushels pitted in the open at Lake St. Martin reserve. The pit is well covered, placed so that it is also well covered with snow. It is also satisfactorily ventilated. The root cellar, erected at Swan Lake Reserve has proved quite satisfactory and the children are getting a meal of vegetables every school day with bean, corn and pea soup. Considerable corn and tomatoes were canned by the children, under the direction of the teacher's wife. These provided a real meal during the months of November and December. The beans and peas were threshed by the pupils by tramping methods on a canvas floor. Raw carrots are given daily and much appreciated by the children, without authority from the Department I allowed this school a quantity of wood for summer firing, $15.00, as it is intended to supply the children with a hot meal during the spring and summer months. Results of a similar nature could be initiated at other Day Schools where married couples are installed. The single school-teacher is satisfied just to teach school.

I submit the following report on schools in the Portage la Prairie Agency inspected during November, 1946.

SWAN LAKE DAY SCHOOL

Mrs. Schellenberg is now in charge of this school. The roll call is for 28 pupils and I found 22 present. The grades are as follows:

Grade 1 - 16
Grade 2 - 8
Grade 3 - 2
Grade 5 - 2

The pupils were well clothed and clean. The class-room was tidy.

This year the pupils had a good school garden. The vegetables are stored in a cellar adjoining the basement and are used for the noon lunch. They have a good supply of potatoes, turnips, carrots, and onions. The garden certainly has proven worth while, and no doubt, required close supervision by the late Mr. Schellenberg.

The school and outbuildings were painted last summer and present a good appearance.

The attendance is good and the pupils appear to enjoy their school work.

Swan Lake Indian Day School
Inspector's Report.

We have now received the inspection report as submitted by Mr. Leckhart after his visit to the above Indian Day School on November 6. Under the heading "General Comments" he makes the following remarks:

"I made my official visit to Swan Lake Indian Day School on the above date. After Mr. Schellenberg's death last year, just after the opening of the fall term, Mrs. Schellenberg carried on for the balance of the year. Mrs. Schellenberg had no teaching experience whatever and I can see that the school slipped back considerably. Mrs. Schellenberg's chief contribution to the school, previous to assuming the teaching responsibility, was to teach the girls to sew and cook. She had them prepare and serve hot school lunches and in this respect she accomplished a great deal.

"I doubt very much that Mr. Smith is any too happy in this position. He is a bachelor, with no car, and finds living conditions rather lonely. This is an ideal set-up for a married couple. The residence and grounds are in good shape with a wonderful garden, fruit trees, etc. Mr. Schellenberg liked this type of work and he carried on a number of experiments in conjunction with Mr. Leslie, Superintendent of the Morden Experimental Farm. As Mr. Smith is..."
not interested in this particular type of work I am of
the opinion that the garden and grounds will not receive
very much attention.

"School Garden - "This has slipped badly. In previous years
where the root-house and cellar was stored with potatoes,
carrots, turnips, onions and ripe beans, this year there are
only potatoes. The garden had been stripped by the time
Mr. Smith arrived on the scene. As a result the hot noon-
day meal will suffer accordingly. Previously a hot meal was
being served by this time of year, but as yet no effort has
been made to carry out this project.

"Handicraft - "I doubt very much will be accomplished in this
department. Mr. Smith is not very handy with tools but feels
that he can achieve the same ends through athletics. I doubt
this very much but there is very little that can be done
about this at present.

"School Work - "I have already intimated that the standard of
the school has slipped during the past year. I also recommended
that certain work books should be supplied but evidently these
had not been requisitioned. Mr. Smith informs me that he now
has a requisition in for work books covering all his grades
I - VI. These should prove to be of great help once they
arrive.

"In summing up this report I would say that the
discipline, manner, attitude and response of the students appears
to be fairly satisfactory although a good deal of hard work
will have to be done to bring the school up to the standard of
a year or so ago. I doubt very much if Mr. Smith, working by
himself, can accomplish these results.

"I made inquiry about the school bulletins
which are being sent out regularly and these were all in
good order."

The Inspector has also recommended that a new
flag be supplied and this has been sent to Mr. Smith. He has
also recommended that a fence be placed around the school garden. Would you please keep this in mind for next year and obtain an estimate as to how much this will cost, so that we can have this work carried out in the early spring.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, November 27, 1947.

Dear Mr. Lockhart:

We have received your inspection report of November 6 upon the Swan Lake Indian Day School. I am sorry to note that the school slipped somewhat during the period Mrs. Schollberg taught there. Mr. Smith did quite well at Pekangokwa, which is in an even more isolated situation than Swan Lake. We will hasten to fill his requisition for workbooks and textbooks which he has requested. We have also mailed a flag to him, as one had apparently not previously been requested.

With regard to the fence, we decided to proceed with the work required in the interior and exterior of the school and to supply the fence next year. We spent over $300.00 in carrying out general repairs to the school and also supplied a sewing machine and general miscellaneous articles at a cost of about $150.00.

I have written to Mr. Waite concerning the comments which you make about the school garden, school work, etc., and have asked him to pay special attention to these items during his future visits to this school.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Baldua, Manitoba.

Swan Lake School:

While I was in the Regional Supervisor's office in Winnipeg, Clarence Cameron, a member of the band came in to complain about the school, saying that it was not being operated full-time and that Mr. Reynolds was letting his wife do the teaching.

If these Reynolds are the young couple who conducted the schools on Oxford Lake there is little to choose between them. The children might even benefit by the joint handling of the school programme.

My attempt at an inspection did not, however, materialize, at this time as Mr. Supt. Hamilton was not available to make the trip. I did, however, get word to Dr. Best of the United Church Missions, and I understand that he has visited the school and made some suggestions calculated to make its operation more agreeable to the Indians whom it serves.

(sgd) C.A.F. Clark

Oct. 16th, 1923.

Rev. J. H. Edmison, M.A.

Dear Sir,-

Today my cheque for Sept. quarter arrived, that is, the grant from the Indian Department. There has evidently been some mistake made in filling out the amount. The cheque calls for only $78.34, one month's salary instead of three. My grant is $900. per year from that source, ($225. per quarter,) and the regulations state that when a teacher is on steadily as I am no deduction is made for summer holidays. They have never deducted salary for July and August heretofore, and it is simply an error this time.

Further July was not a holiday for me, I spent it, at the request of the Indian Dept. studying latest in teaching methods at Winnipeg and my salary from the Dept. is now $950. per year, from Sept. 1st/23. But the increase was to cover cost of the course and as they advanced me $50. the increase will not be shown on the cheque until next Sept. Time taken off during Assembly was made up in August by opening before the usual time, so you see my holidays were really cut down to two weeks.

Please draw their attention to the mistake in salary for July, August and September and it will no doubt be rectified at once.

Yours truly,

(sgd.) Jas. A. Donaghy,

P.S. Our School is very much over-crowded now, but we have hope of a new building accommodating at least 40 next summer. Today's attendance was 26 and seats for only 20.

J.A.D.

In reply I beg to enclose a copy of circular letter of the 17th ultimo, copies of which were sent to all Indian agents and they were requested to forward a copy to each teacher in their agencies.

I beg to acknowledge your communication of the lst. inst. re 10% reduction of salary to start with the lst. of this month. Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6248, file 544-3, part 1)
Ottawa, May 2, 1932.

Dear Mr. Cooper:

I have your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the 10% reduction in the salaries of teachers of Indian day schools. It is true that the superannuation deduction is paid by the Treasury in the case of Civil Servants who are on superannuation and are drawing salary of less than $1,200, but, may I point out that you are not under any of the superannuation schemes and you do not contribute. Teachers of Indian day schools are not considered permanent Civil Servants and therefore cannot benefit by the provisions of the scheme. Of course, any payments you make to the Church superannuation scheme are not considered by the Government.

Yours very truly,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Sir:

In your letter of October 10th, 1932, you stated that, as a midday meal was not required at the Swan Lake School, it would not be necessary to pay for the preparation of same. Owing to the reduction in our Appropriation and the fact that a midday meal is not being served, it has been decided to discontinue this payment. You should so inform Mrs. Cooper.

Your obedient servant,

OPERATIONS MEMORANDUM
TO ALL HOLDERS OF IMMIGRATION MANUAL

No. 32 (Revised)
August 26, 1964

Subject: Sponsorship by the Canadian Armenian Congress

1. The Department has concluded an agreement with the Canadian Armenian Congress to the effect that we will accept applications submitted by the congress for the admission of families of Armenian origin from certain countries without numerical limit.

2. The countries are Algeria, Egypt, Greece, Iran, Iraq, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Libya, Morocco, Syria, Tunisia and Turkey. In addition, the congress may sponsor immigrants from these countries who are residing in a country of Europe where a Canadian Immigration office is established.

3. Stage B will be dealt with in the normal way. Therefore, applications for persons residing in Algeria, Iraq, Libya, Morocco and Tunisia will be accepted only when the immigrant comes within the categories in 7.07 or 7.11 of the Manual.

4. The immigrants must be:

(a) desirable persons who do not meet in full the normal occupational requirements; or

(b) socially or physically handicapped, provided they do not come within the classes described in section 5 of the Act other than paragraph (b) in respect of tuberculosis only or paragraph (c); or

(c) admissible as sponsored relatives under section 31 of the Regulations and the financial or economic position of the potential sponsors is not yet secure enough to warrant approval under current procedures.

5. In ALL cases the Congress must assume full responsibility, i.e., the Congress will be the formal sponsor, even though a relative in Canada is eligible under the Regulations to sponsor the immigrant. The Congress must guarantee suitable accommodation, adequate maintenance, assistance in finding employment when required, and such other help as the immigrants may require to ensure their successful establishment in Canada.

6. This responsibility must be accepted by the Congress for five years or until the persons sponsored become eligible for Canadian citizenship, whichever is
Operations Memorandum No. 32 (Revised) (con.)

the earlier.

7. Each application must be accompanied by a form of guarantee (text in Appendix A) under the letterhead of the Canadian Armenian Congress and with a subject heading identifying the immigrant(s) on whose behalf the application and guarantee are being made.

8. Immigrants certified under section 5(b) of the Act for tuberculosis may be allowed entry as non-immigrants for treatment, provided that the Congress furnishes adequate guarantees for treatment and care until the condition is regarded as cured, as set out in 8.82 and 8.84 of the Manual.

9. The approving office will indicate in the "REMARKS" space on the Imm. 55 that visa is to bear the notation "SPD - Canadian Armenian Congress" and the name of the approving office.

10. In ALL cases, when the usual requirements have been met, the officer dealing with the case will send duplicate Imm. 655* to the Chief, Admissions Division, requesting Order in Council authority for the immigrant's admission. If the immigrant is not in possession of a passport or certificate of identification acceptable under section 27 of the Regulations, the officer will also request the necessary Order in Council authority to waive the passport requirement.

11. When visa is granted to a person sponsored by the Canadian Armenian Congress, the visa officer will write under the visa the notation "SPD - Canadian Armenian Congress", the BHQ file number and the name of the approving office.

12. (a) Statistics will be maintained at Regional Headquarters concerning the number of family units and total number of individuals involved under headings of applications approved and refused.

(b) Regional Administrators will mail their initial consolidated reports to the Chief of Operations for arrival at BHQ on 27 October 1964 and at quarterly intervals thereafter. Nil reports will NOT be required.

(c) Officers in charge will submit an immediate detailed report to the Chief of Operations concerning each refusal.

Ottawa, October 6th, 1936.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your letter of the first instant regarding the supplying of midday meals, your letter of August 18th, last, distinctly stated that $150.00 would be sufficient for purchasing midday meal supplies required at all schools in the Portage la Prairie and Manitowah Agencies. It should, also, be kept in mind that biscuits are supplied to all the schools in these two agencies.

Our records show that the total amount expended last year for midday meal purposes for the schools in these agencies was, approximately, $166.00 and, as our appropriation this year is limited, this amount should not be exceeded during the current academic year.

Yours truly,

A. P. MacKenzie,

Dear Sir,

I was recently on the Swan Lake Indian Reserve, and wish to advise the Department regarding the need of paint for the Indian Day School.

I understand Mr. Christianson, Superintendent of Agencies, has authorized funds to paint the farm residence. The school is nearby and is equally as badly in need of paint. The two jobs could be carried out at the same time and no doubt a saving affected.

The paint and labour will cost approximately $80.00 and I urge that this expenditure be incurred.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

OTTAWA, Ont.
EXD.

Ottawa, August 25, 1937.

Dear Mr. Hamilton:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 21st instant, in which you ask for the authorization necessary to proceed with the painting of the Swan Lake Indian Day School.

I may state by way of comment that we have in the Estimates for this year the sum of $200.00 for digging a well, piping and pump at the Swan Lake School. Is it your intention to proceed with this work? If so, will the sum of $200.00 be sufficient to paint the school in addition to the above mentioned improvements? In view of the fact that Mr. Christiansen has authorized you to proceed with the painting of the residence, it might be advisable to paint the school at the same time. I regret, however, that it will not be possible to provide a sum exceeding $200.00 for repairs and improvements at the Swan Lake School this year. You might consider the matter and undertake the work which may appear to you to be the most urgent.

Yours truly,

R. A. Reay,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Indian Springs, Man.,
Feb. 17, 1941.

Mr. J. White,
Portage la Prairie.

Dear Sir,

I am much disappointed that the biscuits for the Swan Lake Indian Day School have not arrived. The meat and other provisions which you sent in November, 1940 will soon be gone. If the Department were to send biscuits, we could do without any other material for lunch. Will you please use your best offices to urge the Government to get the biscuits? If more children come as you expect, the biscuits will be a great help to me in making provision for lunch.

Thank you.

Yours sincerely,

J. H. Elbert.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

The soft water tank at the Swan Lake Day School is pitted with small pin holes, so many that repair is impractical. This tank is approximately three years old and there is danger of it bursting and flooding the basement. I beg to suggest that a new tank, built of cement be installed.

The toilets are also done, with the exception of the roofs which could be used again. I beg to recommend two new children's toilets.

The material for the toilets could be used for forms for the cement tank, previous to being used for the toilet walls. The tank would be 5' X 7' X 6' high. The material 24 sacks cement,- $24.00, 6 yards gravel,- $24.00. The material for the toilets would cost $16.00 each, and the labour for both jobs,- $50.00. The approximate cost of toilets and tank, labour and materials,- $130.00.

Will you please advise in the matters mentioned above.

J. Waite,
Indian Agent.
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

August 21, 1944.

The cookstove at the Swan Lake Day School is practically unserviceable. It requires new grates, a new lining to the firebox and the oven door is broken. The oven door cannot be repaired.

Mr. Schellenberg, the teacher, does considerable cooking for the children during the winter months. He has a splendid school garden and uses the oven for roasting potatoes and cooking beans that have been grown in the garden. The oven can be used, but a lot of firing is necessary and this is unsatisfactory.

A second-hand stove can be purchased locally, from Mr. DeReo? I am informed that this range is in first class condition and can be bought for $20.00. If this purchase is approved by the Department, I would suggest the old stove be given to an Indians for hauling the new range to the school.

J. Weite,
Indian Agent.

I beg to request authority to purchase provisions for midday meals for the various Indian Day Schools in this Agency to the amount of $260.00.

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, 26th October, 1945.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

With reference to your letter of the 16th instant, the Department will allow an amount of $225.00 during the current academic year for the purchase of supplies for the midday meal purposes in Indian Day Schools in the Portage la Prairie and Manitowapah Agency. This is the same amount as was allowed last year.

In view of the payment of Family Allowances it is reasonable to suppose that the Indians should be in better position to supply food for their children and also to supply them with more food for their midday meal. Under the circumstances, we are not increasing the amount that we formerly allowed for midday meal purposes. As you are already aware, we also supply the usual quantities of biscuits.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

March 18, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

The following repairs are required at the Swan Lake Day School.

Paint for basement floor and walls, grey.
Repairs to basement walls. The walls are badly cracked due to wet fall and heavy frost.
Basement steps repaired.
Basement windows to be repaired. Some of the frames are becoming rotten.
Repair cupboard in basement, also tables & benches.
New battleship linoleum for tables in basement. This to be requisitioned.
Walls of small room to be repaired. Plaster and burlap patched, inside to be painted. Paint and labour.
Door to basement to be re-hung.
A new book case to be built, 5 X 6, two doors, five shelves. Material, hardware and labour.
Blinds repaired.
Varnish all desks, chairs etc.

I have asked for costs on the above work and as soon as they are received a further report will be forwarded.
The above repairs should not be expensive, but they give the school a delapidated appearance.

A new fire-pot is required, as the old one is badly cracked. The furnace is a McClary, 270 "Sunshine".
A new ash-pan is also required for this furnace. I will endeavour to obtain prices on the above and forward together with the costs of installing.

Swan Lake Indian Day School
Inspector's Report.

We have now received the inspection report as submitted by Mr. Lockhart after his visit to the above Indian Day School on November 6. Under the heading "General Comments" he makes the following remarks:

"I made my official visit to Swan Lake Indian Day School on the above date. After Mr. Schellenberg's death last year, just after the opening of the fall term, Mrs. Schellenberg carried on for the balance of the year. Mrs. Schellenberg had no teaching experience whatever and I can see that the school slipped back considerably. Mrs. Schellenberg's chief contribution to the school, previous to assuming the teaching responsibility, was to teach the girls to sew and cook. She had them prepare and serve hot school lunches and in this respect she accomplished a great deal.

"I doubt very much that Mr. Smith is any too happy in this position. He is a bachelor, with no car, and finds living conditions rather lonely. This is an ideal set-up for a married couple. The residence and grounds are in good shape with a wonderful garden, fruit trees, etc. Mr. Schellenberg liked this type of work and he carried on a number of experiments in conjunction with Mr. Leslie, Superintendent of the Morden Experimental Farm. As Mr. Smith is..."
not interested in this particular type of work I am of
the opinion that the garden and grounds will not receive
very much attention.

"School Garden - "This has slipped badly. In previous years
where the root-house and cellar was stored with potatoes,
carrots, turnips, onions and ripe beans, this year there are
only potatoes. The garden had been stripped by the time
Mr. Smith arrived on the scene. As a result the hot noon-
day meal will suffer accordingly. Previously a hot meal was
being served by this time of year, but as yet no effort has
been made to carry out this project.

"Handicraft - "I doubt very much will be accomplished in this
department. Mr. Smith is not very handy with tools but feels
that he can achieve the same ends through athletics. I doubt
this very much but there is very little that can be done
about this at present.

"School Work - "I have already intimated that the standard of
the school has slipped during the past year. I also recommended
that certain work books should be supplied but evidently these
had not been requisitioned. Mr. Smith informs me that he now
has a requisition in for work books covering all his grades
I - VI. These should prove to be of great help once they
arrive.

"In summing up this report I would say that the
discipline, manner, attitude and response of the students appears
to be fairly satisfactory although a good deal of hard work
will have to be done to bring the school up to the standard of
a year or so ago. I doubt very much if Mr. Smith, working by
himself, can accomplish these results.

"I made inquiry about the school bulletins
which are being sent out regularly and these were all in
good order."

The Inspector has also recommended that a new
flag be supplied and this has been sent to Mr. Smith. He has
also recommended that a fence be placed around the school garden. Would you please keep this in mind for next year and obtain an estimate as to how much this will cost, so that we can have this work carried out in the early spring.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

We the undersigned residents of that portion of the Province of Manitoba known as the Dog Creek Reserve, humbly showeth—

That our children are laboring under great disadvantage at the present to acquire an education—owing to the distance of over three miles that they have to travel to attend to the nearest schools—and particularly during the cold winter—

Water New River Boarding School

Situation: This school is situated on the Water New River Reserve, in Treaty No. 2, Manitowahk Agency. The P.O. address of the school being Winnipegosis, Manitoba.

Denomination: This is a Roman Catholic school. Both English and French are taught.

Land: There is about ten acres of land in connection with the school. (There is no correspondence on file in reference to title or ownership of this land.)

Buildings: The buildings in connection with Water New River Boarding School are as follows:

1. The School House: A log building on stone foundation, 30x30 ft., with a clerestory above. This is used as a classroom for Day and Boarding pupils.

2. The Main Building: With a frontage of 70 feet, 24 feet deep, T-shaped and one story high, is where the Boarding pupils are housed. It contains the Dormitories, Dining Room, Recreation Rooms, and Kitchen. It is heated by stoves.

3. Woodshed: 12 x 14 ft.; (4) 2 Stone houses, each 12 x 15 ft.; (5) Horse stable 12 x 16 ft.; and (6) Cattle stable 14 x 14 ft.

Accommodation: There is accommodation for 20 pupils.
History of School

Day school (1) The work of building the first Day School on the Water New River Reserve was commenced by the Indians in 1880. The Deptt contributed in 1882 the sum of $50.00 to procure such articles as may be necessary for the completion of the school house. A further grant of $44.40 was paid in 1883 towards completing the cost of the building, making a total amount of $94.40 contributed by the Govt. to build the first day school on the Reserve. This building was finished and ready for occupation in August 1883. It was a log building 20' x 30' ft. worth when finished about $150.00.

On May 18th/83, the Indian Commr (the Hon E. Dewdney) was instructed to procure a suitable teacher and one Jules Sabourin was engaged.

(2) During the summer of 1892 the Indians commenced work on a new school building "as the old school was becoming useless" and applied to the Deptt through Mr. M. Lock for a grant towards completing the building. In the Estimates for 1893, a grant of $650.00 was voted for that purpose. Tenders were called for the work and two were submitted but were both found to be in excess of the grant provided for that purpose.
It was then decided to have the work done by Indian Labour under the supervision of a foreman "working by the day who may engage at the Reserve such other assistance as he may require."

The following payments were made by the Dept towards the cost of completing the school on the 28th April 1893 a cheque for $50.00 was sent in payment for material supplied on the 6th July 1893. Cheque for $250.00 was sent in payment for material supplied on 18th Sept 1893. Cheque for $100.00 was sent in payment for lumber supplied on Oct 14th 1893. Cheques amounting to $74.63 were sent in payment for supplies purchased on the 22nd Dec 1893. Cheque for $281.85 was sent in payment for material supplied and work done on building. This made a sum of $806.48 being the total cost contributed by the Dept towards the building of the school at the Wali New River.

The building is of log 31 x 23'10", on a stone foundation with a store room above. It is the building which is now used for classes taught by the Day and Boarding School pupils. A wood shed 12 x 16 ft was also built at this time and payment therefor is included in above.

In regard to the main building which the principal mentions in his annual report for 1900 as being 70 x 24 ft. "shaped" and whether...
used to house the Boarders and contains the Dormitories, Kitchen &c. There is nothing on file to show when this building was erected and no amount has been provided in the estimates towards the cost of its construction. It was probably built at the expense of the Roman Catholic Church Authorities.

Per Capita Grant

The first grant made by the Deptt. towards the support of a teacher at the Water New River, was provided in the Estimates for 1883-84, when £300.00 was voted for salary of Day School Teacher. The Day school continued to receive this yearly grant of £300.00 from its start in 1884, up to the end of the fiscal year 1895-96.

The Boarding School was first started during the year 1890, being run in connection with the day school. The Estimates for that year (1890-91) provided for 10 pupils @ £60.00 per capita. This grant for 10 pupils was voted annually in the Estimates for the fiscal years 1891-92, 1892-93, 1893-94, 1894-95, and 1895-96.

On the 3rd March 1896, the Deptt. performed Inspector Mr. Coll. that from the end of the June quarter 1896, the...
Department would cease to pay the $300.00 a year allowed as salary for the teacher of the Day School, but would instead pay a maintenance grant of $60.00 per capita for the boarders up to the authorized number of ten pupils and a tuition grant of $12.00 per capita for those and the day pupils in attendance at the school. By this arrangement the school was placed on the same basis as other boarding schools.

No grant will be voted in the Estimate for 1901-02 for a Boarding School at Water Hen River as Boarding School was closed on the 30th September, 1900, having become amalgamated and the pupils transferred to the Pine Creek Boarding School; however will be conducted a Day School.
at Water Hen River to meet the requirements of the Indians and will be carried on so long as the attendance of pupils warrants it being kept open. It will receive the usual Day School grant of $300.00 per annum.

Amalgamation of Water Hen River with the Pine Creek Boarding School

Mr. Inspector Marlatt in his report on the Boarding school at Water Hen River conducted under the auspices of the R.C. Church authorities gives it as his opinion that this school should be closed. His reason being that the attendance is irregular and that the school is not necessary on account of the proximity of the Pine Creek Boarding School, and that better results could be obtained from one large, well conducted school than from two small ones.

He therefore advocated the amalgamation of the two Boarding schools of Water Hen River and Pine Creek, and that the grant to the latter be increased and the pupils at Water Hen River transferred to Pine Creek, thus leaving only a day school at Water Hen River which would be sufficient for the needs of the Indians at that point.
The Archbishop of St. Boniface, the Principal of the Pine Creek Boarding School and the Indians themselves were in favor of the scheme.

The Water Street River Boarding School was closed Sept. 30th 1900, the pupils being transferred to Pine Creek Boarding School.

Adam, Principal of the boarding school situated at Water Hen River, which was lately amalgamated with the Pine Creek Boarding School, I beg to say that this school appears to have been closed at the suggestion of Mr Inspector Marlatt with the concurrence of His Lordship, the Archbishop of St Boniface and the Department (See letters turned out on file 96150 herewith) There is nothing on file to show that any mention was made of transferring any school equipment or payment for the same by the Department, and previous to Mr Adam's claim there was nothing to show to whom this equipment belonged.

There was a day school at Water Hen River as far back as '82, and I find on referring to Agent Martineau's reports that in '89 there were four pupils boarding at the school, but nothing was allowed for boarders until the year 1890, when provision was made for ten pupils, which was afterwards increased to fifteen in 1895.

Mr Adam has been in charge of this school since 1888, but who owned the equipment or who paid for it I am unable to state.

Water Hen River, 29th Jan., 1903.

The Minister,

Sir:

But to disorganize our reserve Mr. Marlatt has made use of many other means, which we leave for your Excellency to appreciate. One of these means has been to ask Mr. Adam, who has been the school-teacher here for a number of years, to use all his influence to persuade everyone on the Water Hen Reserve to go to Pine Creek, promising him that if he succeeded he would obtain for him a much better situation than that which he was enjoying then. Seeing that he did not attain his ends and that Mr. Adam absolutely refused to misuse the mission that the Government had entrusted to him, he has, in order to close the school in spite of him, used absolutely disloyal means; and it is of the greatest importance, Sir, that you should be warned thereof.

Knowing that our boarding-school was our property, and that nothing could meddle with it, without our consent, Mr. Marlatt called a general meeting of all the Indians of Water Hen to ask them whether they would agree to the closing of their boarding-school. They replied that they would oppose this energetically; that they were determined to keep their school and that they were unanimously opposed to its being closed.

Mr. Marlatt had foreseen the difficulty. He knew well we would hold on to our school, of which we were justly proud, since the official reports made by Mr. Marlatt himself showed that it was the best school in his district.

Under these circumstances he found nothing better to do than to take with him an interpreter who nuts, in his interpretation from Saulteaux into English, tell him just the contrary of what the Indians replied: that is what happened. This interpreter told Mr. Marlatt, in his free interpretation, that the Chief, the councillors and the others desired that the boarding-school
It was thus, Sir, that one day we learned with consternation that our dear school no longer existed. That was the means employed by Mr. Marlatt to do us a great wrong.

Since that time we have been without a school. They take our children away from us by force to send them to the Pine Creek School, which we are obliged to do nevertheless in spite of ourselves, for we understand the importance of education and we do not want to let our children stagnate in ignorance.

Victims of these injustices we come, Sir, to ask your Excellency that our boarding-school be given back to us, because it has been taken from us by fraudulent means and without our consent. We ask that we be given a master to conduct it; we ask that the Water Hen Reserve may become again what it was, and we very humbly pray your Excellency to consider that we do not ask anything that is not strictly and perfectly just.

Dear Sir,

First allow me to apologize for writing on too-expensive paper, but we in the north can not just phone Kelowna delivery when we run out of writing pads so please excuse me.

Your letter requesting a report on the life and training of Indian children during and after school years, I regret to say was accidentally burnt, but answering it as best as I can from memory, I would do make the following statements.

First, I agree that our school program of studies are not, perhaps, quite all that could be desired. Our readers, for example, while they may be very sweet for little girls contain little to inspire courage, manliness or interest in teenage boys.

Sincerely allow my boys to choose the reading lesson. They
never choose a leader, but either "Round the World" or Canadian History—and nine times out of ten they choose the only "taunted tales" story or the Buffalo Hunt," or the large geography.

I must express my very real pleasure in our new arithmetics; they are without exception the best I have ever seen. My boys are doing wonders with them. My only regret is that I have no excuse to order Book three. I am keenly interested to see it.

Your letter spoke of manual training. The idea is right, but the difficulty, as I see it, in day schools, is this. Personally I know I am competent to teach woodwork—but how many badly teachers are—while I would be taking the boys who would supervise the girls. I can also teach needle craft and domestic science. But again, while I would be in the house teaching say cooking, who would supervise the boys left in the school?

If men were substituted for women teachers, I do not see that it would help, as few could teach needle craft and domestic science. One way, would be to employ a woman to take the girls while the teacher takes the boys.
as in most Reserves there is at least one Indian woman who is good at needle work. But then again few indeed are any good at all in housekeeping or cooking. They scrub and sweep the floors until I have become so tired of seeing the brown curlicues round that I shall take the woman, for goodness sake put it away; but I have yet to meet an Indian woman who would dust shelves without being told.

MEMORANDUM:

THE HONOURABLE THE MINISTER,

I am returning herewith certain correspondence relating to the operation of the Waterhen River Indian Day School, Waterhen Reserve, province of Manitoba.

There is an Indian population of 105 on the Waterhen reserve and, of these, 24 are of school age. There is on this reserve an Indian day school with a pupil enrolment of 10. Sister Patricia Fuller, the present teacher, has been in charge of this school since 1929, and, prior to that date, she was in charge of the Indian day school at Bloodvein, Clandeyoey agency, Man. The Inspectors' reports on the work of this teacher are uniformly satisfactory over a long period of years.

It would appear that this school was closed at the end of the academic year 1933 but was re-opened early in February, 1934, in response to a petition signed by the Indian parents on the reserve and on the recommendation of the Indian agent. There is nothing on file to indicate that requests have reached the Department at any time in recent years for the closing of this school.

The Indians of this reserve are, without exception, recognized in the census report as Roman Catholics. It is assumed that the additional 14 children of school age on the reserve are enrolled at the Pine Creek Residential School. This residential school has an enrolment at this date of 114 pupils. A per capita pupilage grant of $165.00 is paid for 100 pupils. The school...
school management received no allowance for the 14 additional pupils and the last Auditor's report states that the cost per pupil per annum is $174.79.

Mr. Adams' statement, that the Superior or Principal of the school at Pine Creek is anxious to close the Indian day school on the Waterhen reserve, in an attempt to have all the children of the Band transferred to the residential school, cannot, in my judgment, be taken seriously. Archbishop Sinnott has always taken a sympathetic interest in the work of this school. He protested vigorously to the Department against the closing of this school a few years ago. In a letter to the Department dated November 12, 1933, Archbishop Sinnott stated:

"Unless the boarding school has demonstrated its immense superiority to the day school, I think it a pity that these day schools should remain closed, or even that they should be closed temporarily. If it is a question of the qualification of the teachers, we should endeavour to remedy the defect as quickly as possible."

I feel confident Archbishop Sinnott would be vigorously opposed to the closing of the Waterhen River Day School at this time.

I am enclosing herewith, for your information, an excerpt from a report on Indian education, sent forward to me on May 10, 1937, by the present teacher of the Waterhen River Indian Day School, Sister Patricia Fuller.

Director.

Dear Sir,

As His Grace Archbishop Adenot of Winnipeg informed me that you are now the Superior of the Indian Dept., I am addressing this report and petition to yourself, so it would seem that these reports are properly filed in the mainline way.

I have stated in nine reports to the Dept., and the Agent has seen for himself, the failing condition of this school and teachers buildings. The latter never has had any paint.
either inside or out, the floor is simply worn out. However, it would never look clean if scrubbed daily. The furniture belonging to the Department consists of an old broken bedstead and spring to wear out mattress, one table—home made—and three chairs, two of which I myself, could not dare to sit in (all remains) and a cook stove. All remaining furniture heater, tables, desk, kitchen utensils and crockery, I have had to purchase myself according to the national curriculum I am supposed to teach drawing, knitting and sewing. The drawing books are simply ignored on my requisitions. My last supply being in 1927 those once supplied seven dollars worth of books myself. I have ordered them again or last month's requisition, however, I have received each year...
30 yards of flannel, but it has come in November. How can I even take time to teach little girls to make underwear when they are shivering in our own homes? Yarn has come also, except this winter and it did not come at all. Of all the cruel sights it was to see the poor little children with bare hands and cotton stockings in so bitter a weather. Material and yarn and needles to be abused in this school showed reach there was later in September 1st.

The Department for the last few years gave my boys pants, for which we are very grateful. But when I have spoken to the agent about the material & yarn he has told me "how expensive the yarn is and what if the parents can not afford to keep their children they must put them in the Boarding School, that is what the Boarding Schools are for."
If this is the dept policy I am afraid I fail to see any wisdom in it. First, how is the cheaper to completely maintain a family of from 5 to 14 children in a boarding school for ten years each, than to supply a few pounds of meal and a few pounds of sugar, also a few pairs of rubbers. The half breed children have received complete supplies of clothing including rubbers, while my poor little ones had not even a mitt to put on while carrying in the school wood; their poor little hands freezing with the contact of ice & snow while pulling out and carrying the wood.

Again, is it wise to train parents to believe that they need have no responsibility of their families, all they have to do is to bring into the world as many children as they can, then throw them to the government to raise.
Most of the parents who love their children do not wish to throw them away. They have to see them go to Day School practically naked because there is not even a rabbit or fish to catch, so during the winter and spring, at the same time they see the halfbreed children warmly clad. This spring also there are few or no rats to be caught.

States it, sir, that you have a copy of the "Regulations Governing the Employment of Teachers in Indian Day Schools." I would like to respectfully discuss a few points in it.

Alto I have been teaching Indian Day schools for sixteen years, now is the first time I have received the Regulations in writing.

I wish it to be clearly understood that although I may have to mention from time to time my own experiences, I am doing so only to emphasize my point, and not to plead
my own cause... this is no call but I wish to plead for justice for our younger teachers.

I am sure the Dept. can not realize the indignity of the pay school teacher's position, she or he is neither just, clear, nor fair.

The teacher knows that her salary comes from the Dept., and what she earned pays not me cost for either her maintenance or the upkeep of the school. Yet any priest can come in here and what have to open or close the school or on any day she can order it closed. He can come in here and what she is or is not to teach. If she has the conviction that so the Dept. learns all the financial expenses & has written definite rules regarding school regulations that she should obey the Dept. rules that the priest, there is a battle royal if she is considered as a bad teacher. Then along comes the Dept Inspector & agent both demanding school inspections & discussing
active matters. She Ottawa sends along for reports.

When the Personnel Record Card was sent me last year, I had to write the Agent to know just exactly who my immediate superior is. He wrote back that it is himself, so other teachers and government employees then what might have priests to get angry when the teacher refuses to delay opening her record until ten or ten thirty for days at a time just because they can not say their mass at time. They tell me that the church comes first, that they put the teacher in the school to serve the church, then why do they not pay her salary, and by what authority do they demand school inspections?

Section 4 of the Regulations states "Teachers..."
must hold complete academic or professional certificates." Presumably this is a new ruling, and a good one from the pupils' point of view.

Of the six Catholic teachers I have met, four were French Canadians totally unfit to teach English even to English speaking children. To teach Indian children was quite impossible. Out of a school of thirty-two pupils from grades I to V not one child could express the simplest sentence she read. I took this school from a teacher who had been here five years; his highest pupils were only in grades I & II.

I said the ruling is a good one from the child's point of view but what of the teacher's position? She must be a fully qualified teacher from the White Dept. If she stayed in the White Dept she would eventually receive her superan-
nutrition allowances. She has also her "teacher's association" to give her moral and legal support. She takes an Indian Dept school and loses her standing in the White Dept and is less than nothing in the Indian Dept. She has no recognition or protection of any description.

Elevation men, office boys and typists are all come under the protection and benefits of the Civil Service Act. But teachers, as myself often serving its aspect in sickness or health for sixteen years—so long that any other line of business is now impossible are simply cut out by both government and church. Both have received the best of the teacher's years, yet both let her loose like the Indian does his dog at the end of the winter's work. His dog runs thro' the woods he will be
caught to secure the next position, but if he should die no one gives it a thought.

I had decided to resign at the close of this term, but on both his grace the Archbishop & the Indians have begged me to remain I have promised to do so for one more year solely to see my two grade VII boys and one grade P girl - to whom I am teaching cooking and music - through school. The parents told me plainly they will never send their children to boarding school & that if I leave they will take their children out of school altogether. These children being exceedingly shy, I know would fail with a new teacher at this period. Having taught them through kindergarten and having known them for nine years I should know how they react to various situations. These children
being deeply interested in their studies,
this news has made me feel the wrong

the 1938-39 terms. This sacrifice is

Sections 142 are rather too long to quote,
has the Dept given a thought of the
injustices and impracticalities of such

I fear the impracticability of it.

First, she teaches an average of eight grades dividing them into seniors and juniors. She has to teach every child to understand English before she can commence teaching English subjects.
