Take them either right into the Indian Dept., with the same standing as all other Dept.'s servants or cause the Church to take full responsibility, making them absolutely Church servants. Although I suggest this alternative, I do not think it would be wise, owing to the amount of Reserve work to be done what does not concern the Church. The teacher's position now is an impossible one, she belongs to everyone yet she belongs to none.

I beg to remain

Yours respectfully,

Re: 126-12-1

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter dated May 12th, last, with enclosure being a copy of letter received by the Department from Miss Patricia Fuller, Teacher, Waterhen Day School.

It is true that the Teacher's residence is of old construction and is not worth repairing. I have placed an amount of $2500.00 in estimates for a new teacherage. The inside walls of the school were washed on May 25th, see voucher No.1217 and are not in bad condition. However, school should be painted inside and out next year and an amount covering labour and material is placed in next year's estimates. The furniture was purchased for the Sister about seven years ago and is not adequate, but I would not suggest new furniture until a new teacherage is erected.

The Teacher has made repeated complaints about not receiving the articles she requisitions from the Department. From time to time she has asked for a certain drawing book, and others have been substituted, until now the desire for this special book has become an obsession. Flannelette has been shipped into this Reserve as soon as received from the Department. Yarn and needles have also been forwarded as soon as received. The Teacher has an attendance of six boys and three girls. Boy's pants were shipped into this Reserve to outfit all the boys and thirty yards of flannelette together with yarn should go a long way to outfitting all the children she has attending school, and as the articles of wearing apparel are made at home by the parents of the pupils, the month of November is early enough for these supplies to be shipped.

All families on this Reserve are on direct relief during the winter months and in my opinion the children would be better cared for in the boarding school. This also appears to be the visiting Priest's point of view, and is a point of contention between him and the Teacher.

There is not a resident Priest on the Waterhen Reserve. A travelling Missionary from Pine Creek School holds a mission on the Reserve three or four times a year and it appears to me that the Teacher could co-operate with the Missionary Priest during these times instead of getting into a "battle royal" every time he is on the Reserve.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA.
In regard to superannuation of teachers, the contents of Department letter were made known to her. The Teacher at the time of my visit was determined to resign at the close of the 1939 term, however, as this is a periodical threat, I do not place any stock in her intention.

The Teacher was very emphatic in stating that she has absolutely no interest in Department regulations. The intention of her writing was for the protection of younger Teachers coming after her with a view to making their condition easier on Reserves at outlying points. The living costs enumerated in her letter are those she paid at the Bloodvein Reserve during the years 1926-27 and the expenses shown also refer to travelling and hotel expenses during those years. The grocery costs and travelling expense are considerably lower at the Waterhen.

The Teacher also stated that she prefers isolation to city life and would not consider being moved to a Reserve where conditions might be more congenial. Her serious complaint is, that being only a member of the Third Order of St. Francis she is only a third degree Sister with little or no connection with the church, and she is not in line for superannuation as she is not a civil servant.

In summing up, I wish to say, that in my opinion the Teacher is "bushed". I also wish to refer to various reports to the Department in which I have stated that the Teacher is nervous and in need of a holiday. These outbursts are periodical, usually occurring during the long grind between Christmas and the end of the term. I have repeatedly told Miss Fuller to take full advantage of every holiday and get away from the Reserve even if the holiday is of only short duration. Her complaint is that she does not have the necessary funds, her claim being that the cost of living was too high to allow her sufficient money for holidays. This was investigated in her presence and a reasonable balance sufficient for holidays was shown. She then intimated that she was still paying the funeral expense of her parents who died many years ago. I concluded from her conversation along these lines that she has lived so long on isolated Reserves that she is afraid to go out into civilization. She complained of insults taken from young Priests on missions to the Reserve. These insults when sifted were nonsensical to a degree of foolishness.

I would suggest that the Teacher be given more work to occupy her mind. From her letter it appears that she is overworked, such is not the case, as she is of a brooding temperament and broods if her time is not occupied.

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your report of the 5th instant, relating to conditions at the Waterhen Indian Day School, and to thank you for the information contained therein.

In view of the comparatively small enrolment at this school, I am not at all sure that the Department is justified in keeping it open and in operation. It is just possible that the pupils now in attendance might be transferred to residential schools, although most of our residential schools, it would appear, are at the moment filled to capacity.

I feel confident you will agree with me when I state that the Department would not be justified in spending the sum of $2,500.00 on the erection of a teacher's residence. I note, with interest, that all the Indians on the reserve are now in receipt of relief allowances. I am anxious to know if it would not be possible to have these Indians take out logs during the winter months and assist in the erection of a teacher's residence, on the understanding that the Department would purchase the roofing, windows, flooring, etc. Should the Indians consent, it is just possible we might have to allow those actually engaged in the work additional rations. Dear Sir,

I received your letter of Feb 26th 44 reminding me of my apparent mistake in including the names of absent pupils on my September Returns, and referring me to instructions on the Day School Returns. Instruction no 6 covers non Treaty children only of which I have none. If not on the quarterly Returns, where are the names of Treaty Treaty pupils to be reported.

About twelve years ago one father brought his children back to the Reserve late for school.
opening. The agent sent him a reprimand, not until the fall of 1942-43 had I any more truant pupils. Then in Oct. 1942 four children did not return until Oct. 26th last September seven pupils failed to report, two of which returned Oct. 18th and the last was not until Nov. 15th.

At the Treaty meeting of 1942 Mr. Haite impressed on the men that they were expected to go out to assist with the harvesting, but he did not say that on the day the school was closed, everyone was to rush off to town.

That fall when four pupils returned late nothing was said. Last fall seven pupils took from four to four & a half months vacation. Still no reproof was given. What will it be this fall?

When I complained to Mr. Haite and Mr. Hamilton, that besides ruining the school discipline,
it is impossible to teach properly
with half the pupils returning
at different times. They answered,
"that the Indians must earn
their living, and that if the
wives want to go with their
husbands there is nothing to
prevent them."

Until 1942, our women earned
their living digging seneec
roots, while the women and
children kept the gardens and
ate from them, and also picked
berries. The return of the children
to school on time was taken
for granted. Now the discipline
is so spoiled, the mothers ask
for their children to miss
school on every possible and
impossible excuse, especially,
so, in this with the girls.

The mothers more than the
fathers are absolutely indifferent
to the benefits of education. This
indifference has naturally spread
to the children. This June
will be the second year that
a number of pupils will be
unable to pass their examinations.
This failure is not only the
result of indifference, but of poor
feeding. During the winter of
1942-43 only one family had
vegetables, which had measured
to each family the following:
seeds sent via the Dept = 2 oz ea
of carrots and turnips and 1/2 oz
of onions. Both summers
nothing could be seen in the
gardens but weeds. The family
who had vegetables stayed home.
There were no crop reports made
in 1942-43. There was simply nothing
to harvest and so nothing to report.
The skin diseases and minor
sicknesses among the children
this winter has been the worst
in my fifteen years here.
1943-44 is a ten months term.
Up to date some pupils have already
missed three months. It would
take a smart—besides a well fed!
child to pass a yearly examination without only a six months or less tuition. These children are neither.

There may be no law preventing mothers leaving the Reserve all the summer, but there certainly is a school act ordering children to return to school on the correct dates.

I would like to suggest that the present term be extended until the end of July, and that the vacations be from July 28th to October 9th. This will keep the mothers and children on the Reserve during the garden growing season. The one week in October will allow parents time to return after the harvesting. We could take the Easter week to make up this one week.

I would further wish to suggest that Mr. Poile be asked to speak strongly at the next Treaty meeting—1st on the duty.
of parents keeping good gardens for the benefits to their families,
2nd of the benefits of an education,
and of the Indians obligation to the tax payers to use to the full these benefits. 3rd. That it is obligatory for all pupils to be present on the opening dates.

Another reason against these people leaving the Reserve in July is the fact that they find little or no work. The farmers have finished seeding and the harvest is not ready. Having no steady work, the young men get into trouble in poolrooms and beer parlors, while the girls pick up with strange service men.

It must be remembered that this Waterhen Band does not consist of Indians, but of treaty half-breeds—and a very poor type.

I have it on the authority of the priests, and the police, and
also from what these people themselves have told me, that even in harvest time, these men do not work steadily. With only one or two exceptions they are of no use to the farmers. Their contribution to the war effort is absolutely nil; neither do they benefit themselves or families. They do not bring home any new clothing, nor food supplies, nor even money, but have to get straight into debt at the store, much to the store keepers annoyance.

I would further suggest that the police at Winnipegosis and Dauphin be asked to keep a closer watch on our young people, with authority to send home young men convicted of drink, and families whose mothers do not keep the children properly, especially the young girls.
I beg to remain

Respectfully yours,

Patricia T.O.S.F

Re: 208-11, March 24, 1944, Sister Patricia's letter.

In reply to the above noted letter and enclosure being a letter addressed to the Department by Sister Patricia, Teacher, Waterhen Reserve, I beg to state that there is very little I can say in reply to same. It is the usual type of letter that has been received about this time of the year, over a period of years. It is true that I have encouraged Indians of all reserves to go out to work and I feel that they have been a great help to the farmers all over the Province. It is also true that in the majority of cases very little money was brought back to the reserve, although the average Indian is better clothed than he has been for some years. In fact many Indians are extravagantly dressed. The harvest and threshing operations, in many parts of Manitoba, were delayed last fall through rain, and after threshing Indians were occupied in cutting cordwood, until close to the opening of the winter fishing season. This condition is due to the war and will not be righted until the war is over. The Indians, even from the most inaccessible reserves, were out last summer seeking work. In all my reports on this situation I have pointed out that gardens are bound to suffer, and especially in these reserves where transportation in and out is costly. The Indian will not work out and leave his wife and family at home. Neither will the wife stay home while her husband is away. The whole family moves out to work and all the family work if work is to be obtained. Sister Patricia is aware of this condition and, as you know, it has been pointed out to her that this will most probably right itself after the war when the Indian's services will not be in such great demand.

Over.

I have to report on the situation as regards the appointment of a teacher for Waterhen Day School, following the resignation of Mrs. Denise Langhan.

Mrs. Langhan's resignation was received 17th November, and Regional office was advised immediately. Resignation was to be effective December 20, 1948, the end of the Fall term.

Reference your letter of January 6th under file #545-1 (EL).

I wish to say that we have been unable to locate any teacher as yet for the Waterhen Indian Day School at Waterhen Reserve.

Only last night I returned from an Inspection of that reserve, and the following is what I have found with regards living quarters at that point.

The living quarters are badly in need of re-decor -atang, the kitchen stove is old and broken and should be replaced at once. There is little or no equipment for the kitchen, very little furniture, and the upstairs (1 room) has only two beds, one old dressing table, two mattresses one of them should be destroyed.

In other words this residence presents a very gloomy prospect for any teacher going in there to teach.

While at that reserve I called a meeting for all the mothers who had children attending the day school, and of the sixteen children attending, (13) of them are willing to enter the Pine Creek Indian Residential School until the end of the June term.

I would suggest that these children be allowed to enter the Residential School, and during the summer holidays the Waterhen Day School should be redecorated, and equipped the same as our other Indian Day Schools.

Please therefore advise us on your decision so that we may be able to advise the parents of the children.

Dear Father Lavigne:

I have for answer your letter of July 25, and I am pleased with the results of your advertising for teachers in the Ensign. You will probably note that I am advertising also - particularly for our requirements in Saskatchewan and Alberta. Therefore, I have written to the Saskatchewan teachers who answered your advertisement in an attempt to interest them in positions in that province and possibly in Alberta.

Seine River School

Mr. Desmarais has been transferred to the Caughnawaga School. It is too bad for the Seine River Indians as he was a very good teacher. However, he is just the type we need at Caughnawaga, and he is not lost to us.

You are probably aware of the isolated situation of the school at Seine River, and I hope Mr. Hogue also knows of conditions there. I am enclosing some photographs given me by Mr. Desmarais which you could show him so that he will be fully aware of conditions. If he accepts, we will try to have the school painted at once. (Would you please return the photographs after showing them to him?)

I attach one of our application forms which he should complete and return here at once. I presume he has no teaching certificate nor experience. His salary would, therefore, be only as a Grade I teacher at the rate of $108.00 a teaching month.
Waterhen Indian Day School

Mrs. A.C. Buddrus is already teaching for us at Moricetown, B.C. I will write to her concerning this transfer.

Whitefish Bay Indian Day School

Mr. P. Fenez has decided to stay another year here as we are building a new two-room school. I believe the school will be finished about November when we will need a second teacher. I am writing also to Mr. A.J. Callaghan to interest him in either the second room at Whitefish Bay or in the new school at Northwest Bay (Fort Frances Agency) which we should be opening soon.

I will be expecting to hear from you in the near future concerning Mr. Rogue.

Sincerely yours,

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

September 7th, 1949.

Mr. Roland Gagner,
35 Clarence Street,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Mr. Gagner:

We are in receipt of your telegram of the 6th instant advising that you have been unable to proceed to the Waterhen Indian Day School owing to your mother's illness.

Under the circumstances mentioned, we approve delaying your departure to the school and it is hoped that you will be able to proceed not later than September 15th. Please let us hear further from you regarding the exact date on which you will begin duties.

Sincerely yours,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division

November 12th 1925

Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
F. N. Paget Esq.
Chief Accountant

Dear Sir,

Referring to your letter of September the 14th 1925 stating that I was in error about the payment of service as Distributor of Medicine, for which I stated was $45.00 per quarter, and for which cheque of $45.00 had never been received at that date.

In reply to this I must say that the cheque of $45.00 in question that I claim is for payment of service as Distributor of Provision for the June quarter 1925.

When I wrote to you on Aug. the 25th claiming $45.00, I was under the impression that I was receiving $45.00 for Medicine, and that the $12.50 cheque was for provision, as stated to me by the Indian Agent, but I see now that it was changed about when he explained it to me.

I hope you will see that this matter is straightened out.

I remain
Yours Truly

Aristole D'Amour
Ottawa, December 1st, 1925.

Sir:-

In reply to your letter of the 12th ultimo, I beg to say that previous to March 31st, 1925, you were allowed salary as teacher of the Waterhen River Indian Day School at the rate of $600.00 a year. This amount was paid on a basis of ten teaching months in the school year. In addition you were allowed bonus at the rate of $150.00 a year which was also paid on a basis of ten teaching months. These two amounts made a total of $750.00 which you were paid for your services as teacher.

Payment of bonus to teachers of Indian Day Schools was discontinued on March 31st last but from April 1st 1925 your salary was increased by $150.00. Since that date you have been paid salary at the rate of $750.00 a year which you will note is the same amount that you received when you were drawing bonus. This amount is paid on a basis of ten teaching months in the year and therefore for quarter ending June 30th, in which there were three months, you were paid three-tenths of $750.00 or $225.00. For quarter ending September 30th in which there was one teaching month, you were paid one-tenth of your salary, or $75.00. There is therefore, no balance due you as teacher.

In addition to your salary as teacher you are allowed the sum of $50.00 a year for issuing provisions, medicines, etc.,. This is paid in quarterly instalment, and payment for the June and September quarters has been made. There is therefore no balance due you in connection with this.

I trust that this letter will fully satisfy you.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education,

Anatole D'Aoust, esq.,
Teacher,
Waterhen Indian Day School,
Skowman, Man.,

Sir:

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

Dear Sirs:

The writing of this letter is a great pleasure to me, as it is to recall my resignation sent to you in June last, from the Bloodvein Reserve Day School, Lake Winnipeg.

The Rev Oblate Fathers have transferred me to the above school. Again thanking the Dept: for all the consideration they have shown me in the past seven years, and hoping for many more years service in the Dept: of Indian Affairs.

I remain

Your faithful and obedient servant

Sister Patricia Fuller J.O.S.J.

P.S. Would the Dept: please note the slight change in my mode of address "Sister" instead of "Miss".

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6248, file 545-5, part 1)
Sir,

In connection with Indian Boarding Schools to which per capita grants are paid for the board, lodging, clothing and education of Indian children, I have the honour to inform you that the Department desires to have the following requirements insisted upon, viz:-

1st. Comfortable lodging should be provided and sleeping apartments for girls and boys to be entirely disconnected, well ventilated, and kept scrupulously clean.

2nd. A sufficiency of wholesome and nutritious food to the extent of three meals a day.

3rd. Suitable clothing for winter and summer and change of under-clothing once a week at least.

To secure these the Department instructs, Everything connected with the institution to be regularly or periodically enquired into, approved of, and reported on by the Indian Agent for the locality once a month, and the schools to be subject to his inspection more frequently if he deems it necessary.

I have the honour, etc.

(Sgd) A.H. Forget.
Asst. Commr.

E. McColl Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
I presume that Mr. Adam bases the present claim on the grounds that the school was closed by the Department and for this reason the articles enumerated are of no further use to him, the school was closed by the Department, but with the consent, advice and concurrence of the Roman Catholic Church under whose auspices it was operated, and I am of opinion that if Mr. Adam has any claim it is against that body.

Many of the articles in the account are such as are required in ordinary family use and as Mr. Adam has a large family I cannot see that it will be any hardship for him to retain them or dispose of them as he may see fit, with reference to the dwelling it is customary for teachers leaving a reserve to dispose of their dwelling to the incoming teacher and no doubt Mr. Adam will take advantage of this opportunity.

Finally, I am of opinion that Mr. Adam has no claim in law, or equity, against the Department and that the claim should not be entertained. Should you think otherwise and decide that all or part of the items should be assumed by the Department I would recommend that no action be taken until a valuation can be fixed by an officer of the Department as the prices asked are in my opinion excessive.

I have the honour, &c.

(Sgd) S.R. Marlatt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Portage la Prairie, Man.
24 Dec. 1900.

Ref: Your Letter No. 122/51 of 20th inst.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of above date regarding the claim of Mr. J.H. Adam, amounting to $890.90, I beg to report as follows:

I have made a diligent search through the files in this office and can find no data that would support the account; all I find points the other way. Neither can I find any reference as to the conditions on which the school was started; I find a letter written by Mr. A.E. Forget, Asst. Indian Commissioner, to Mr. R. McColl, Inspr. of Indian Agencies, of which I herewith enclose a copy which would lead me to suppose that the Department accepted no financial responsibility other than a per capita grant; no other inference can be drawn from the opening clause of the letter attached.

I also find from a letter of Mr. McColl, to Mr. Martineau dated Feb. 10th, 1890, that the Department refused to pay an account of $185.00 made by Mr. Adam for the erection of a teacher's dwelling on the ground that the expenditure was not authorized and that no provision had been made for it in the estimates. I cannot find that this claim was again rendered which would lead me to suppose that Mr. Adam had concluded that the claim was not good against the Department.

Hon. David Laird,
Commissioner of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

I beg to herewith enclose, for your consideration an account amounting to $890.90 received from Mr. J.H. Adam, late Principal of the Indian Boarding School, at Water Hen River Reserve.

About four months having passed since then and receiving no answer, would you kindly inform me if has been forwarded to the Department, if it has been recommended for payment in full by the Inspector, and if I may soon expect a favorable decision from the Department.

I beg to remark that I have received $110.00 in account from the Principal of the Pine Creek boarding school, leaving a balance of $890.00.

Ottawa,
April 30, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Provision has been made in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1940-41 for an amount of $1500.00 to erect a teacher's residence at the Waterhen River Indian Day School. Please let me know if you would recommend its erection by day labour in charge of a competent foreman. Would additional white labour be required or are there competent Indians who could do the work under the direction of the foreman?

At what time would you recommend that construction start, also where would you suggest that the material be secured? Any other information that you can give to assist us in arranging for the erection of this building should be supplied.

An immediate reply would be appreciated.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir,

Re: The enclosed report on water supply.

Up to last year water was taken from a small spring near the school. This water was used by many on the reserve. All this for the past four years was quite unfit to drink. Last year it went completely dry. I myself have to pay 25¢ per barrel of water, at this price, I can not afford to supply the pupils with water for washing dirty hands after recesses, and drinking, two very serious problems. So dirty hands means soiled books, the Indian child deserves much drinking water, which I have ever encouraged. For fear Indians owning horses, can easily get water, but for others it is certainly
hard for them to pay for water, which means the lowering of sanitary conditions. They could not afford much water for washing either bodies or clothing.

I strongly suggest that a well be dug this spring. The men, I know, will do the work, if the Dept. will supply the cribbing. Yes, it will cost a few dollars, but not nearly as many as future hospital bills will cost, if these Indians are forced to continue to drink water in which cows stand in, and use as a toilet. This is a daily fact. Even to get clean, pure water, mothers have an average of 5 miles to go when the men are away. This is quite a problem for young mothers.

I seriously think the time for getting things done is past; Ottawa waited, and correctly so, that we can not afford medicines & hospital bills," yet, what am I, as dispenser, to do, with this ghastly water condition, no child under 14 yrs of age has been vaccinated or inoculated, some years ago I had just case of typhoid, but I had, then, medicines, and several case cases. Now
I have no such things.

I wonder if you would be interested in a little measure I have taken to conserve paper and needles.

Some years ago when orders came, "sandbags were not to be used in future" as they were considered unhygienic. In some schools this may have been true, but not in mine, as wet and dry bags were compulsory, which were washed every week. I soon realized at seeing so much paper wasted by little ones unable even to write their letters, so I gave them back their slates using white chalk instead of slate pencils, chalk being rubbed off instead of washed. Teachers who are advanced sufficiently to use writing books, still use slates or pieces of small blackboard for drill work. Next year, three little ones will commence school, they will not have writing books until they enter grade 1. I figure this will be a saving of an average of 14 books during the term, quite a consideration if all schools did the same during the
present paper shortage.

Erasers were so often getting lost and swept up, that I have cut all erasers in halves, and have tied short strings thro' the thick part & a little stick on the other end of the string, so each eraser has its owner's initials on it. Further each pupil has his own pencil box, and at each recess or closing time I sort if each box has its little felt meaning eraser, since in a general settle of boxes, to show me what our fingers are in, I had found that whole erasers were being destroyed. Now, being fairly small to start with, they are being neither destroyed or lost.

I remain

yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Sir, Re: 126-12-5, May 1st 1942

I beg to acknowledge receipt of Department letter as above noted in which you advise that Sister Patricia has asked for a well to supply her with drinking water.

It is true that the water in Waterhen lake is very low and I am very doubtful if a well could be dug to sufficient depth to obtain a supply of water. The situation at this reserve is very similar to Lake St. Martin where the school and residence are built close to the Lake shore.

The experience at Lake St. Martin was that water seemed unobtainable in close proximity to the lake shore and I am afraid that the situation would be the same at Waterhen. However I will look further into this matter at treaty payments and will try to obtain a 12' drill and test the ground in the school area.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6248, file 545-5, part 2)
WATERHEM INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

I found 16 children present, and the roll calls for 22. The 'Flu was bad on this reserve, and the attendance had been somewhat lowered on account of this. A number of the children present had severe colds, and no doubt would have been better at home.

The school is in charge of Sister Patricia Fuller who appears to be quite capable, although she has no Normal training.

The children are shy and timid as they rarely see outsiders. They appear to understand their work, and I would judge that fair progress is being made.

The school and teacher's residence are in good repair. The school was clean, and appeared to be well equipped for school work. The residence is fairly well furnished, and I understand is quite comfortable.
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

Sir,

I am in receipt of a letter from Sister Patricia, Teacher at the Waterhen Indian Reserve Day School in which she advises that difficulty will be experienced in providing water for the children's midday meal this coming winter.

She suggests that the Department supply her with a ten gallon tank and thirty cents per week to pay a man for hauling water.

The cost of the tank would be approximately $4.00 and $6.00 for hauling water for the season.

I would recommend this.

Will you please advise.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

We have for acknowledgement your letter of August 2nd regarding the Waterhen Indian Day School, I must agree that this school was in very poor condition and should have been attended to long before this time.

Which ever figure is granted, I will make it a point to do my best to see that this school is clean and tidy for the new teacher.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, enclosing an estimate of the material required to finish a house for the use of the teacher in connection with the Waterhen River Indian Day School. This appears to be the first intimation the Department has received that a house is being erected for the teacher's use. We note, however, that the Indians have the building erected and require the lumber, hardware, etc., to complete it.

In view of your recommendation that this material be supplied, I have to say that you may arrange for the purchase and delivery of the quantities of lumber, shingles, doors and window frames and hardware, as enumerated in the bill of material for which you obtained prices. The tenders which you forwarded for the material required are returned herewith, for your information and to be attached to the vouchers for payment. If there are any other firms from which you desire to obtain prices, you should do so and in any event the materials should be purchased from the firm quoting the lowest price. It is understood that when this material is supplied the Indians will do the work of finishing the house without cost to this Department. When forwarding your accounts for the material, please furnish a brief statement descriptive of the house erected, giving dimensions and other particulars. The total expenditure for material to finish this house is not to exceed $300.

Your obedient servant,

The Indian Dept., Ottawa, Ont.

Dear,

His lordship, the Bishop of Moncton, directed me to send in School Reports of St. John's School, York Factory, by this Mail, and therefore I enclose School Reports for three quarters of 1900. The Reports may not be filled up as they should be, but as I never saw a complete form, I had no idea as to how they should be done. You will, therefore, kindly excuse mistakes. It will be seen from my Reports that the number of School days fell far short of the 216, but it must be taken into consideration that I am a missionary who has to travel a great deal, in order to preach the Gospel to the wandering people scattered over this vast district. I have not yet found any man or woman to whom I could entrust the tuition of the children during my absence. In fact, we had not the funds for a school teacher's pay, but now that his lordship assures me that the government will willingly make over a grant of $100 towards defraying the expenses incurred in the tuition of the Indian children, I think I can secure a teacher to carry on the school work during my absence.
There are quite a large number of scholars during the summer when the Indians are here. It is most to be regretted that the Indians cannot stay longer in summer, but owing to a scarcity of food they find it impossible to live together at the fort for any length of time. The Indians of York Factory are the Cree Indians, and are Christians. They barter their furs with the Hudson's Bay Company for goods & provisions, but as a rule they are poor & find existence a hard struggle.

I should be much obliged if the Dept. would send me the Daily Registers, Forms for Quarterly Reports &c. as soon as possible, so that I may be able to use them next summer. Hoping that the enclosed reports will be satisfactory.

I remain

yours truly

R. Harris
C.M.S. Missionary.

Sir,

In regard to the question of erecting a School House at York Factory, I beg to report as follows:

No building is needed for the present as the Church Missionary Society has a very fair building sufficiently spacious which can be made warm and comfortable and will answer the purpose until the Reserve is surveyed and we can definitely ascertain the best permanent site.

My remarks in regard to the situation at Split Lake sent under separate cover apply with equal force in this connection. The Indians are not too insistent on this matter. They wish to be independent of the Missionary Society to have a school house all their own, and to have it on their Reserve which has not yet been located. The speedy erection of such a building would have good effect because it would prove stronger than words that the Department intends to keep all the pledges of the Treaty made with them last summer. They could easily reason from one thing granted to the granting of other things in due time. At present it is a case of faith without any practical evidence except the payments of last August.

The School is at present under the supervision of the Rev Mr Faries an intelligent gentleman of good education and as far as I can learn of good influence with the people. He has School material sent by the Church but when the Payments are made next summer a supply of School Material should be sent in for future use.
When in the wisdom of the Department it is thought fit to erect the School nothing better can be done than to make a grant for that purpose and ask the Rev R. Faries of York to carry out the work. I think that the cost at York will be about £700.00.

There is this difference between this place and Split Lake. Any Government boat going to Hudson's Bay might take in all lumber required. The rates should this plan be adopted I cannot give. To my own mind the old plan of cutting logs and sending in only what is absolutely needed viz doors windows nails and Mica Roofing is the surer plan.

In conclusion I do not see any special need of haste in the matter only this that all correspondence is necessarily slow and the wise man takes time by the forelock and does the preliminary work without delay.

I have the honor to be

Your Obedient Servant

John Semmens

Mr. McLennan Sec'y.

Dear Sir,

I cannot allow the present opportunity of direct mail service, to pass without writing to you something of the conditions here re - the Winter teaching. You will remember I came here this summer under the direction of Bishop Loftus, to take over the work of teaching the Indian School, as a Government worker, with the understanding I was to receive from you five hundred a year.

In your blank forms for Quarterly Returns it plainly states no salary is paid until these are filled out and sent to the Department.

Of course I knew this from past experience, but who would dream to ask for a moment; "Is the school kept open all the year?" when the salary of five hundred was to be received. It was to me a shock I can not easily get over, when during September I went heat to find that not only was there no wood but more could be given, or bought.

I made an appeal to the Indian chief, who said
the Indians were going to take away all the children away but 2 or 3 & they would not get wood, + as the responsibility of the wood was thrown upon me, I appealed to your Agent; Major Howard of Ft Nelson, through whose prompt reply + liberal offer to pay for wood, kept me from going out in the "fall" Canoes. I tried but failed to buy any, the Indians got about 15 or 20 poles, + the three o'clock scholars have gathered wood + chips. The senior boys picked up debris of an old sidewalk, + we purchased axes + chopped this up, but I see no possible outlook for heating a school even to Christmas. We managed to get through the first quarter, + I trust my returns will reach the Department with this mail, but the outlook for school this Winter is as dark as night. It is through no fault of mine, then what about my salary? I have no place of residence, only with the missionary in charge, for which I pay $3.00 a week for my board + lodging.

The Indians have nearly all gone off to the bush + I have begun the second quarter with 17 names on the register, a number more are leaving this week + more when the mail packet returns on the 15th.
Oct 9th Seeing my letter has not gone, I will finish & send by the first opportunity. The attendance at school is so much decreased in members, interest or otherwise that there will be nothing I fear to report at the close of this term. I have the last Quarter's Returns to the missionary in charge to mail to you at Rt Nelson. Personally I thought I should have sent them to your agent Major Howard for his signature but Rev. Faris said No, he would sign & mail them. Will you please instruct me by return of mail, what I shall do with this Quarter's papers, & please write direct to me, either through your agent or straight to me at York. Please do not fail, & may I ask you as a personal favour not to show this letter or answer it to anyone but me. I am obliged to live in the house with the missionary in charge, & do not want to provoke his displeasure. There is absolutely no other accommodation. The Indians will not be back before next June, & imagine me, remaining in this uninviting undesirable place with no school all these months, in order to teach three months in what is called summer. Now Conscientiously & frankly I say I do not want to do this another year. If you will favour me with another school where the work goes on the year round.
I am willing to take it; or the work of nurse or matron, but I prefer teaching, however I trust you do will do me this kindness, & provide one with employment.

When the Bishop was here, he said if I should so desire, he would await on the Department for my salary, & back for one £25 quarterly, I gave him a letter to hand to them so to that effect, because I thought you would not wish to be burdened with my financial affairs.

I have also written to him that owing to conditions etc here I should be glad of a change another year.

I cannot afford my expenses for transportation, unless they were advanced & then deducted from my salary.

Why might I not have a "Pass" as (I believe) some other Government workers have. I only mention this because of necessity. Hoping Gentlemen you will answer. I remain your obediently,

Memorandum:

Honourable Thomas G. Murphy,

It is somewhat difficult to report on the attached extract from a letter from Mr. John Butterfield to the M.S.C.C. It seems to be an arraignment of the Missionary Society and the Government. The school at York Factory is conducted by the Missionary Society and the building belongs to the Society, and if there is any lack of sanitary conveniences, no responsibility is attached to this Department. We give them a grant of $450.00 a year for educating a few Indians who attend.

There are some general observations about education and medical attendance in which there is nothing new,- no helpful suggestions that might be carried out. The writer refers evidently to Treaty Nine Indians; and there is no promise, solemn or otherwise, that the sick will be cared for and that they will not be allowed to starve. The provisions of Treaty Nine are the standard provisions for reserves and annuities; whatever the Department and the Government do in excess by way of relief and medical attendance is done as a matter of grace, and the Treaty Nine Indians have the same treatment as all our other Indians.

The Indians of the district of Patricia can only be visited once a year and that by aeroplane. The Band to which the writer refers is situated at Nikip Lake; it is the Cariboo Lake Band. When the Commissioner met them last year he found them in an impoverished condition, and advised them to meet him next year at Clear Lake where there is a post of the Hudson's Bay Company. They promised to do so. Our information is that the Indians of this district are getting plenty of native food this year, and there should be no evitable suffering.

Re-boarding School in the District of York Factory.

The Indians in this District are anxious to have a Boarding School in our District, so that the children in our Band may be educated. Schools - Indian Affairs Branch

1. Whilst paying treaty at Gillam, Shammattawa and York Factory during the past month, requests from the Chief and Councillors of the York Factory Band were received for the Department to establish a residential school at York Factory to take care of the children at that point, Shammattawa and Gillam.

2. On the whole, the Indians are not satisfied with sending their children out to the school at Elkhorn, Manitoba, and their chief objections would appear to be that the parents do not get to see their children through the year and lose contact with them; the majority of the boys that have returned from the school at Elkhorn are too old to learn how to trap and have a difficult time to make a living in view of the fact that their only source of livelihood is trapping.

3. Their chief reasons for requesting a residential school at York Factory which would accommodate 50 children or more, are that more of their children could receive education without losing contact with their home environment and that the parents would be satisfied to leave the children in school knowing that they would be within close proximity and could see them occasionally.

4. Under the present system, the percentage of their children attending Elkhorn school is very small and those boys which have returned, have not been able to re-adjust themselves satisfactorily to meet requirements.

5. The Indians stated that if the Department would consider establishing a residential school at York Factory, they would supply fresh meat, fish and fuel for the school. Vegetables can be grown at York Factory.

P.S. O.
Schools - Indian Affairs Branch

Continued............. can be grown at York Factory. Other supplies could be purchased outside and shipped in by Schooner via Churchill during the summer.

6. An attendance of 50 children could easily be maintained by the three points, more likely more than an average attendance of 50 could be expected for their appear to be quite willing to send them to school at York knowing that they could visit them once in a while. Children from Severn, Ont might also be taken care of by a school at York, but it is considered that an average attendance could be maintained between, Gillam, York & Shammattawa. There are about twenty-five or thirty children new at Gillam whom could very well be in school, but the parents do not seem to care to send them outside and make excuses wherever possible.

7. In the past, the Department has contributed some $500.00 per year towards maintaining a day school at York, whilst the Provincial Government contributing $200.00 per year, which permits the white and half-breed residents of the district to send their children to school. This has not exactly been satisfactory to the Indians for very few of them live around the settlement through the year, and therefore few of their children had the opportunity of attending the day school when it was in operation. The majority of the Indian families would only be around York during the months of June, July & August, in some cases not even for three months, they come into the Post early in the spring and leave for their trapping grounds early in the fall, and as they have no place to leave their children behind, they are forced to take them along with them.

8. The present day school at York has not been in operation for the past three seasons, I am given to understand that the difficulty is to obtain a teacher.

9. The request of the Indians concerned merits consideration, from my own personal observations, I would be inclined to favour their request and it is thought that maintenance of small residential school at York would not be prohibitive; however, advice from the Department on this matter would be appreciated.

REPORT ON YORK FACTORY AND SHAMMATTAWA DISTRICTS inspected between June 26th and 30th, 1945.

YORK FACTORY INDIANS

The Indians feel that more should be done for the education of their children. The day school has not been in operation for some time—apparently it has been impossible to secure a teacher. In the winter this school might serve about eight or ten Indian children and 15 or more half-breed children, non-treaty. This means some 35 pupils get no opportunity for education. The parents with their families leave early in September and often do not return until late in June so the children cannot be in school. A summer school for such a short period would be useless. If a teacher can be secured I think the present day school should be in operation until something better can be started. In my opinion the teacher should be a married man and in addition to teaching, both he and his wife should carry out certain welfare work. I see no hope of educating the children at York or Shammattawa any way except by admitting them into a boarding school. To build a small boarding school to accommodate 50 pupils at each point constitutes several problems. The cost would be high—freighting in materials would be expensive and keeping a staff would be difficult. A school at York to care for about 100 would meet the needs of both bands and supplies can be brought in twice a year by boat from Churchill. The alternative is to build some place along the Hudson's Bay line and transport the children in and out. The school question is a real problem and one which should be faced.

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

REPORT ON YORK FACTORY AND SHAWANAGAN DISTRICTS inspected between June 26th and 30th, 1945.

It is difficult to determine how best these northern Indians could be served, but I believe the following suggestions, if carried out, would eventually bring results.

1. Establish an Agency perhaps at Gillam with a full-time Indian Agent and Clerk. This would take in York Factory, (Fox Lake and Shawanagana Indians), Churchill Indians, Duck Lake Indians and the Split Lake Band.

2. Place a welfare worker experienced in fishing, hunting and lumbering to supervise York and Shawanagana and another man at Gillam to look after the Fox Lake Indians located at Gillam and also to supervise other groups along the Hudson's Bay line and the Split Lake Indians.

3. Establish a nursing station at York Factory and Nelson House. Sick Indians along the line could go to The Pas - also the Indians from Split Lake.

4. Provide a boarding school at York for the York Factory and Shawanagana Indians - perhaps 35 pupils.

5. Establish a boarding school at some other point for Split Lake Indians (perhaps 30 of school age) and those living along the Hudson's Bay line (another 30). Setting Lake has been suggested as an ideal location. There is plenty of fish, game and wood, and this location is only a few miles from the Railway.

A plan of this nature requires large expenditures and the employment of experienced and qualified help. However, these Indians need not only advise but leadership - practical men who understand northern conditions - men who know how to obtain a living from the surrounding country. We have provided Agents, Farming Instructors, Stockmen, Schools and Teachers for the prairie Indians. I feel confident a similar plan must be followed for the northern Indians and this matter should be one of our post-war programs. The big need is for qualified men as leaders and suitable schools to meet the requirements of many Indian children now growing up without education.
A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies

In November, the Canadian Junior Red Cross had the pleasure of receiving two visitors from Germany: Dr. Goetz Fehr, Director of Junior Red Cross in Bavaria and Dr. Heinrich Leuchter, Director of Junior Red Cross in Hesse. Their ten days at National Office was part of a study visit arranged by the American Junior Red Cross.

Dr. Fehr is emphatic in his belief that Junior Red Cross is the best medium through which to re-educate the youth of Germany. "They want practical actions, not mere words," said Dr. Fehr. "In my opinion," he stated, "Junior Red Cross is the best means to demonstrate that, by working cooperatively together, they can help not only others but themselves as well."

One of the first dolls to come to Alberta was recently given to the Junior Red Cross. To be included in a consignment of toys for children over the 65 years old, Major Shortliffe came west with the Royal North West Mounted Police, and brought this doll for his daughter. She has a complete wardrobe, even including boots and a flower-decked hat. Members of the Junior Red Cross in Western Canada High School, Calgary, assist in getting a shipment ready to send to Britain.
YORK Factory is often spoken of as the "cradle of the Canadian West" because so many of the first settlers entered the country by way of this historic old port and trading post on the west of Hudson Bay. Situated just within the mouth of the Hayes River on a narrow tongue of land that has the Hayes River on one side and the Nelson on the other, it was for nearly two centuries the headquarters of fur trade on "the Bay" and, as such, it knew stirring times and played an important part in the making of Canada.

Its importance as a point of entry and business centre dwindled with the building of railways to the west until, today, York Factory is merely a ghost of its illustrious past. Yet, like other famous trading posts around the Bay, it is still mantled with an aura of glamour and romance.

We visited this historic spot last July. We sailed down the Bay from Churchill to York Factory on a little packet ship just as many an Adventurer did in those far-off early days of the fur trade.

It was shortly after dawn when our ship entered the Hayes River and anchored in mid-stream opposite the trading post, but long before it had anchored, the Indian village that stretches a mile or more along the high river embankment was wide awake. Some early riser had seen us approaching and quickly spread the news, and now men, women and children poured from tents and log cabins, talking excitedly in their high-pitched musical voices.

The packet ship's arrival is always a big event at York Factory. It happens only once, or sometimes twice, each summer and all the things seen and done on that occasion provide topics of discussion for many a week after. Some of the Cree children were seeing a ship for the first time in memory, and watched it in round-eyed amazement. I waved to them from the deck but, at that, some hid shyly behind their mothers' skirts, for a strange white woman was not to be welcomed lightly.

As soon as the anchor dropped, Indian men and older boys hurried to the landing, eager to begin the task of unloading the ship. It would be tedious, but a pleasure too, to unload such interesting boxes and bales, and cartons and barrels as stacked the decks and stowed the hold to capacity. They could scarcely wait for the post manager to go aboard and conclude the necessary business formalities with the captain.

The colour and pageantry once associated with this occasion have long since disappeared. Had it been a hundred years ago, booming cannon would have announced our arrival, and skirling pipes have escorted the post manager, proudly decked in red coat and gold braid, when he walked from the door of the great trading post to greet us at the shore. Instead, when we visited the post a pleasant young man in business suit came aboard to welcome us and to arrange about getting the cargo ashore.

The upper photograph is another view of (quoting Mrs. Eva Beckett) Gitche Waskihigen, the Great House, at York Factory Manitoba.

The lower photograph shows the left bank of the Hayes River where the houses are unoccupied except during a few weeks in the summer season.

From personal examination of the Great House, I can vouch for the accuracy of Mrs. Beckett's statements that "most of its vast storage space is now unused -- most of the business once transacted here has swung north to the seaport town of Churchill."

This vast substantial wooden structure might, if the company were willing, provide the floor space to accommodate in every way 200 Indian children, perhaps even more.

It could serve the Protestant children of parents who patronize Hudson Bay posts at York Factory, Shambtawe, God's Lake, Oxford Lake, Split Lake, Churchill, and points within the approximate circle which the places named enclose.

Water routes at certain seasons are open along God's River, Hayes River, Nelson River, Churchill River, and the coastal waters of Hudson Bay. Even Island Lake is part of this age-old river system. The Hudson Bay Railway touches the Nelson River about 90 miles upstream from York Factory.

Indian children in the area under discussion have occasionally attended Residential Schools at such remote points as Ekhorn and Prince Albert. While some of the Indians appreciate the efforts of these Residential Schools, they decline to permit their children to be sent so far away.

I have used the term "Protestant" as the area is served mostly by the Anglican Church in Canada and the United Church of Canada. Each is experiencing difficulty in keeping missionaries and teachers at the various isolated posts in the area. By co-operating at York Factory they might each contribute to the educational progress of their people, and at the same time administer to the spiritual welfare of their respective adherents.

Dear Mr. Neary:

Thank you for your letter of June 23rd. For York factory Joint school—Mr. Davis wrote me to this effect some time ago. He also suggested that if necessary; he would be prepared to pay slightly more than $20.00 per month.

I lost the teacher that I had for Anama Bay—transferred my York Factory teacher there and have hired another boy—on the strength of Mr. Davis letter, for York Factory. If satisfactory to you—we will pay him $1400.00 and suggest that you pay his board whatever that may be, possibly $30.00, but not more. This boy is a 1st.B, class teacher with experience both in country and village schools. I anticipate the payment of transportation from the railway to York Factory as well.

Mr. Davis suggested the inclusion of money to build a teachersage at this point in next year's budget. I believe that such an undertaking would cost in the neighborhood of $2500.00 dollars. The material for the teachersages that I am building costs me $1400.00 in Winnipeg. If you want to build as suggested please let me know so that I too can include our share of the cost in my budget.

Re-Anama Bay—Is it your intention to continue paying the Indians share of the teachers board at this point? If so I would suggest that you pay both this teacher and that of York Factory direct. The teacher will then realize more fully that this is a joint effort.

yours sincerely,

Bernard Grafton,

Dear Sir:

Re: File 519-1 (E)
Jack River C.E. Indian Day School

Thank you for your letter of July 18 which came to hand on August 6th on my return from an extended visitation of our Indian Missions in the Hudson Bay area and the northern end of Lake Winnipeg, which occupied my time and attention for a month.

I visited Churchill, York Factory and Jack River, Norway House, as well as other points in the northern area of our Diocese, including Split Lake. Teachers are required for York Factory, Jack River and Split Lake, and thus far we have no applicants for any of them. We should be pleased to hear from you as to any Anglican applicants, or other suitable teachers.

I may say that on the occasion of my visit to Split Lake from July 22nd to 25th, the teacherage was not erected, although it was expected that the same would be duly constructed by Mr. Blend and Mr. Hadley, the Hudson's Bay manager and free trader respectively.

It is understood that Mr. Retallack, the Hudson's Bay Company manager at York Factory is being transferred, hence I presume the services of Mrs. Retallack as teacher will not for long be available.

Yours sincerely,

(sgd) J. Keewatin

Attention - Bernard F. Neary, Esq., Supt. of Educ.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your telegram of Oct. 3rd, following please find information requested.

No. 1. Attendance Indian Children York Factory School.

Ten children are attending at the present time. This attendance will probably rise to twenty in the near future, as families are expected to move in from Port Nelson.

No. 2. Progress Construction New Schools in Agency

Oxford House School, No. 1 has been completed, with the exception of installation of Selkirk Chimney.

God's Lake United Church School is also completed, with exception of Selkirk Chimney.

When these chimneys arrive it will be only a matter of hours to install each one.

I made a final check on God's Lake United Church School on Oct. 17th.

This building has been completed sufficiently to legalize payment to the Contractor.

However the finishing was an extremely hurried job and reflects no credit to the man concerned.

The living quarters especially are very poorly painted and finished, the cupboard doors do not fit and the paint has just been slapped on.

In the Main Class Room, the small windows on the North side are fitted with Butt hinges, these hinges were not countersunk; when the windows are closed it leaves an eighth of an inch gap.

The Contractor was told about all this by the Assistant Agent at God's Lake and agreed to rectify it, however it was not done as apparently the main idea was to get finished and get back to town.

Unfortunately, the Contractor had left when I made my final inspection. The whole finish shows a definite lack of interest. In my opinion this man should not be given any further Contracts with the Indian Department.

Attached please find Final Progress Report.
No. 3 Joint Recommendation by Mr. Grafton and myself on New Schools Next Year.

There are no further Reserves in this Agency that would warrant a joint School, due to the lack of Non-Treaty Children.

No. 4 Report on New Teachers.

To date I have only met Miss M. Rahn of God's Lake United Church School, she appears to be doing well and seems to be quite efficient.

I see no signs of Teachers for Oxford House Schools, No. 1 & 2, nor for Split Lake.

Could I be advised as to when these Teachers may arrive?

I would like to draw your attention to the Quarterly Return ending Sept. 30th, 1949, submitted by this Agency. Under the heading "Schools & Education", reference is made to a Permanent School at Shamattawa.

I would appreciate your comment on this matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. H. Staunton,
Superintendent,
Nelson River Agency.

Ottawa, June 7, 1924

Very Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of April 25th, enclosing the March quarter return of the York Factory Indian Day School.

It is noted by this return that there have been only six Indian pupils in attendance and it is also noted that a return showing the attendance of the halfbreeds at this school is submitted monthly to the Manitoba Department of Education.

In view of the small number of Indian children attending it is felt that the Department would hardly be justified in allowing the amount of salary suggested in official letter of December 10th, last. Please inform me what amount the Manitoba Department of Education allows towards the salary of this teacher. When your report is received the Department will be in a position to decide what amount can be allowed for the March quarter.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Ven. Archdeacon R. Faries,
York Factory,
Via The Pas,
MAN.
The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir,

Replying to yours of June 7th, No.138-2-3 - I have to explain that the small attendance of Indian children at our School during last winter was due to the hard winter the people experienced. Fur-bearing animals were scarce, which meant reduced circumstances for the Indians, and they could not afford to live at the Settlement. So the children were taken away to distant fishing places. Since the summer, however, the attendance of Indian children has increased so much that we were obliged to dismiss the half-breed children in order to give ample accommodation to the Indian children.

As to the information asked for - I may say that the Manitoba Department of Education allows a grant of $40.00 a month towards the teacher's salary. The teacher's salary is $1000.00 a year. Besides the salary we have to allow $200.00 a year for operation expenses - transportation, fuel &c., and we cannot draw on our Church Missionary funds for any expenses in connection with the School.

I have the honour to be,

Your obedient servant,

Richard Davies
Archdeacon of York

Very Rev. Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 1st instant informing the Department that Mr. Herbert Cannon has resigned in August last from the position as teacher of the York Factory Indian Day School and that you have obtained the services of Mr. Albert J. Dewdney to succeed him.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the appointment of Mr. Dewdney. We note that he took up his duties on the 1st instant. The salary allowed will be at the rate of $30.00 per month of ten teaching months in the year. Should Mr. Dewdney teach only part time we could only allow him salary on a per ordinance basis of $3.00 per day for the actual days taught, but if he keeps school opened each teaching day in the year, payment will be made to him at the rate mentioned viz. $30.00 per teaching month. He should prepare and forward his quarterly returns showing attendance as regularly as mail facilities permit. It is hoped that Mr. Dewdney will meet with success in the work as teacher at York Factory.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I have much pleasure in forwarding to you the Quarterly School Return for the Indian Day School at York Factory covering the term that Mr. Leonard Fraser was the teacher.

It will be noticed that Mr. Fraser neglected to have the local Acting Indian Agent (who now is stationed at Gillam, Man.) to examine and sign the Return. As it means a long delay to send it back for the Acting Agent's signature, I have examined and signed the Return as the Missionary-in-charge of the Mission where the School is conducted, and I am in a position to verify the teacher's Report.

The Cheque for the tuition given in this School may be sent in the usual way: viz., to the Bank of Montreal, account No. 5078, in Winnipeg, Man.

It may be noticed that there were only six Indian pupils in attendance last Quarter, due to the trapping life of the Indians who have to live on their trap-lines many miles away from the Settlement. After March, however, there will probably be Twenty or more Indian pupils in the School.

I am,

Your obedient servant,

Very Reverend Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 26th ultimo, enclosing the return for the York Factory School for the month of July, it will be necessary for you to forward us a receipt from Mr. G.A. As you have previously been informed, salary is only provided for nine months during the current fiscal year at all Indian day schools.

The fiscal year runs from April 1, 1940, to March 31, 1941, and during that time, as stated above, funds for only nine months' salary are available. Mr. Chunn has been paid for April, May, June and July, or four months of the current fiscal year, and consequently only five months' salary can be paid between now and the end of March, 1941.

Very Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of a copy of your letter of the 8th of April, last, addressed to Inspector W. J. Bayts, Acting Indian Agent, Port Nelson, in which you state that it is your intention to build a school at York Factory during this summer and wish to be supplied with twelve windows, four light sashes, size of glass 3' x 10"; roofing material, ten rolls of three ply rubber, "Dreadnought"; and six rolls of white sheathing paper.

If these articles can be bought locally at a reasonable price, you may purchase them, and forward accounts for the expenditure incurred, in duplicate, properly certified to the Department for payment.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

RN: Estimates for York Factory
Band of Indians 1937-38

1. Whilst at York Factory on patrol; reference to patrol report dated at Gillam, 30.9.36 the Rev. Archdeacon R. Faries interviewed me with respect to an Indian School which he is building at York Factory. At the present time the Indian Dept. is using a small cottage owned by the Hudson's Bay Co. for a school house and it is too small for the number of children who wish to attend school. The Anglican Mission have therefore started to build a new school for the Indians and the Rev. Faries is desirous of having financial aid so that the school may be completed for next summer. I would therefore request that the undermentioned be included in the estimates for the York Factory band for the fiscal year 1937-38. Hereunder is a list of the requirements.

25 Double School Desks to include
5 Fronts and 5 Backs, made up as follows; 5 for ages 10-15 yrs.
10 " " 7-10 "
10 " " 5-7 "

50 Yds. 48" Wide Slated Cloth for Blackboard.
1 38" Camp Comfort Stove.
24 Lengths 7" Galv. Stove Pipe.
2 7" Elbows.
1 7" Downer.
1 Med. Size Flag (Union Jack)
1 Gross Slates.
1 Slate Pencils.
1 Lead Pencils.
1 Scribblers, Pencil Ruled.
1 Exercise Scribblers.

At the present time there are not many Indian children attending school, but during the Summer months of July and August this year there was an average attendance of 33 which is the capacity of the present school. The school which is being built is 20 feet long by 24 feet wide and will have a seating capacity of 50 children. The material used for the building has been bought and paid for by the Anglican Mission. I would also request that the sum of $500.00 be granted to cover the cost of labour for building the school.

Acting Indian Agent.

Sir:

RE: Estimates - 1937-38 Indian Dept. - York Factory Band.

1. With reference to the above attached hereto please find estimates in duplicate for transmission to the Dept. of Indian Affairs.

2. In previous years all the Treaty Supplies have been sent to York Factory and then issued to the various bands at this point. During the last year approximately 65 Indians have established a permanent trapping ground at Fox Lake which is situated about 35 miles N.E. of Gillam and it is requested that the supplies shown on estimates for the Fox Lake Band be shipped immediately to the Cst. I/C, R.C.M.P., Gillam, Man. By having these supplies shipped to Gillam it will do away with the monthly Slick & Substitute Account at the H.B.Co. as rations can be issued direct from I.H. supplies at Gillam. It will also eliminate the usual trip which the Indians have to make from this point to York Factory where they have been receiving their Treaty Supplies.

3. In regards to school supplies, I might state that the new school building at York Factory was completed in September. The articles which appear on these estimates are needed to equip the interior of the school and it is requested that every effort be made to forward same with the annual supplies.

4. Drug requisitions from York Factory and Gillam are also attached hereto. The drugs requisitioned for from Gillam are very small owing to the fact that certain drugs and pills now on hand will be sufficient for requirements during the year 1937-38. Drug requisition from Shemattawa has not been received to date but same will be forwarded upon receipt.

5. Supplies for York Factory should be shipped to arrive at Churchill, Man. not later than June 30th, 1938 so that connections made be made with H.B.Co.

The O.C. - "D" Division,

Extract from Regional Supervisor Davis' report dated January 4th, 1949 on the York Factory Indian Day School.

In the village at the time of our arrival there were 12 Treaty children and 13 non-treaty children. These people live around the settlement. Mr. Grafton, the Provincial School Inspector, made arrangements to open up a classroom the first of the year, and hired the Hudson's Bay Manager's wife as teacher. Both Treaty and non-treaty children will be looked after. This will be a joint school, and, no doubt, the Provincial Government will be taking the matter up with you.

We were unable, owing to flying conditions, to visit the North Knife Settlement, which is about 8 miles north of Churchill and where the Indians are now permanently located. This being half of the Duck Lake Band, which, I understand, split up a few years ago. There are about 150 Indians in each band, as near as I could learn. It is my intention to go in next summer and check over the whole situation, as we may be able to build a school for these people. We were also unable to visit Neultin Lake, as flying conditions in the Barren Lands were bad, and the pilot advised us it was not safe. Part of the Brochet Band live at this point. The settlement, I understand, is very small - only two or three families living there, the rest being scattered. This point will also be visited by myself next summer. I understand from trappers who arrived in Churchill, that conditions amongst these bands were fairly good and no one was suffering.

York Factory Indian Day School,

Dear Bishop Lofthouse:

We have recently had our Educational Survey Officer accompany Provincial School Inspector Grafton through the various settlements in northern Manitoba. You are of course aware of the day school at York Factory and know that it has not been possible to obtain a teacher for the past eight years. Archdeacon Faries was formerly the Secretary-Treasurer of the local School Board and was the moving spirit behind the establishment and maintenance of this school. You will recall that we donated an amount towards the construction of this building and that we paid a contribution towards the salary of the teacher.

Reports from Mr. Clark, our Educational Survey Officer, indicate that the school is in good condition but that the teacherage is unfit for use. I understand that Mr. Grafton has arranged to have Mrs. Metlack, the wife of the Hudson's Bay Post Manager, teach school from January on. There will probably be a very small attendance during the winter but the Indians will attend when the trapping season is over.

As we are anxious to do everything possible to bring educational facilities to these Indians, I would appreciate hearing from you with any comments and suggestions which you would like to make, concerning the operation of this school.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Bernard P. Henry
Superintendent of Education.

Attention - Bernard F. Neary, Esq., M.P.O. of Edm.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your telegram of Oct. 3rd, following please find information requested.

No. 1. Attendance Indian Children York Factory School.

Ten children are attending at the present time. This attendance will probably rise to twenty in the near future, as families are expected to move in from Port Nelson.

No. 2. Progress Construction New Schools in Agency

Oxford House School, No. 1 has been completed, with the exception of installation of Selkirk Chimney.

God's Lake United Church School is also completed, with exception of Selkirk Chimney.

When these chimneys arrive it will be only a matter of hours to install each one.

I made a final check on God's Lake United Church School on Oct. 17th.

This building has been completed sufficiently to legalize payment to the Contractor.

However the finishing was an extremely hurried job and reflects no credit to the man concerned.

The living quarters especially are very poorly painted and finished; the cupboard doors do not fit and the paint has just been slapped on.

In the Main Class Room, the small windows on the North side are fitted with butt hinges, these hinges were not counter sunk; when the windows are closed it leaves an eighth of an inch gap.

The Contractor was told about all this by the Assistant Agent at God's Lake and agreed to rectify it, however it was not done as apparently the main idea was to get finished and get back to town.

Unfortunately, the Contractor had left when I made my final inspection. The whole finish shows a definite lack of interest. In my opinion this man should not be given any further Contracts with the Indian Department.

Attached please find Final Progress Report.
No. 3 Joint Recommendation by Mr. Grafton and myself on New Schools Next Year.

There are no further reserves in this Agency that would warrant a joint school, due to the lack of non-treaty children.

No. A. Report on New Teachers.

To date I have only met Miss M. Halm of God's Lake United Church School, she appears to be doing well and seems to be quite efficient.

I see no signs of teachers for Oxford House Schools, No. 1 & 2, nor for Split Lake.

Could I be advised as to when these teachers may arrive?

I would like to draw your attention to the quarterly return ending Sept. 30th, 1949, submitted by this Agency. Under the heading "Schools & Education", reference is made to a permanent school at Shamattawa.

I would appreciate your comment on this matter.

Your obedient servant,

J. H. Stanton,
Superintendent,
Nelson River Agency.

Pose Colt
Prince Albert
Dec 8 1906

Dear Sir,

Would you please be kind enough to tell us if you have received our school reports pertaining March 31st and June 30th 1906. If you can give us any information it will be very much obliged to you for doing so.

I remain your obedient servant,

James Duthie

Returns for quarters ending March 31st and June 30th have not been made.
Ottawa, December 15, 1906.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 8th inst., I beg to say that no returns were received from the Cross Lake day school for the quarters ended March 31 and June 30, less, and no salary can be paid for these quarters until properly certified returns are received by the Department.

Your obedient Servant,

J. D. McLean

Secretary.

Jonas Deschambault, Esq.,
Prince Albert, Sask.

Ottawa, August 16, 1935.

Sir:

I have to inform you that His Lordship Bishop Lajeunesse, The Pas, has nominated the services of Rev. Sister St. Luc as teacher of the Cross Lake R.C. Indian Day School for the coming academic year, to replace Rev. Sister St. Leonard, who has retired.

The Department is approving of the appointment of Sister St. Luc, with salary at the rate of $85 per teaching month. She is to begin duties when the school re-opens after the present summer holidays, on September third, next.

I have to request that you will give the Rev. Sister every possible assistance in her work at this school, where it is hoped she will meet with every success.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

P. G. Lasenby, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Norway House,
Man.
